reviewText:
(Anyone who is looking for a break down of Planetary Annihilation's as a game, I recommend this review. http://steamcommunity.com/id/voodoochilli/recommended/233250/ by Voodoochilli. The thoughts expressed below are as much about the game of Titans and Uber's poor handling of its community)


Where to begin really. I am a huge fan of Total Annihilation, a massive fan of Supreme Commander 1 and Planetary Annihilation was a dream come true when I heard Uber was making it. However, what we got at the end of the road was not quite what we were expecting. The Original Planetary Annihilation is a solid game, though with some pretty heavy problems that are still unresolved.

So what is Planetary Annihilation: Titans? Its the content you should of received at the 1.0 release of the original game. This is a horrid cash grab and to make matters worse the launch is plagued with bugs. Do you want to restart the game after every match you play? Well that is what some of us are dealing with every time you try to go back to the main menu. So not only is this a shameless grab for your credit card, but it is a buggy mess as well. Nothing in Titans is extremely new beyond units and it is only 21 units. The AI is still broken and nothing is much different. This is not worth the money if you already own the original planetary annihilation, which is fun at times.

I am sorry Uber that you guys really screwed the pooch and PA did not become the success you hoped it would. But that is not our fault and trying to rob us blind because we want to support you is how you sour your fans. Honestly, I think you guys need to close the doors if this is how your treating us now. Your customers will bite you back if you try to abuse us and there goes any hope of you guys being a developer.

Save your money for a better game.

Edit: Now some people have been taking the stance of 'they put a lot of hard work in to this content' and so forth. How much hard work? 21 units and some game modes. How is that a lot of hard work? If you owned Planetary Annihilation, you got a 66% Discount on the game which brings it down to 13 dollars or so. 13 dollars for 21 units that feel like they should of been in the main game. I say should of been because all of this feels tacked on and not the good kind. I mean the fact that its all unpolished and rough around the edges. This is why I say its deplorable. This is not a bug free, polished experience your paying for out the gate and really the fact this is all running on the same engine leaves little excuse as to why they broke their own game.

reviewText:
This is the original planetary annihilation with more units. Still buggy. Will we have to buy another game later if we actually want it to work?!?

It is shameful to charge people for a new game when this still doesn't even live up to the promise of what the original Planetary Annihilation should have been. This would have been ok as DLC, but Uber just want to be rid of their previous negative reviews for how buggy PA is. Unfortunately PA Titans is also still buggy.

Shame on you Steam for permitting this.
Shame on you Uber for doing this.

reviewText:
Oh look, it's another already released game patched a little bit with new text painted over old title and put on window display with shiny price as if it was a brand new thing because developer desperately wants to get on that front page again. Don't you just love this exiting new era of constant indefinitive editions, [payments] extended [due to content] cuts and more and more games feeling like they are all published under Valve's Too Early Access forever, someone just 'forgets' to mark them from time to time as such, kinda like with Towns before it all began?

Well, Planetary Annihilation actually was in Early Access. And like many others there, on it's release date it was just incomplete mess. Mess that no amount of half-asssed insincere attempts of fixing it could change dramatically, because the game not only turned out to be unfinished (do backers and early adopters remember that YT video thrown into main menu playing over intro? Apart everything else that was wrong, how do you miss bugs in release-candidate build that hit you right off?), it was built on flawed fundaments. You can't fix randomly generated soulless skirmish battles mashed together faking single player campaign unless you throw it all away to start over with proper campaign, which they didn't in Titans. Adding some flavour text here and there doesn't give it any more meaning. To some like me the whole basic concept of fighting on planets and even multiple ones at time turned out to be just a distracting, tiring gimmick in practice, no matter how awesome it looked on paper. At least they stopped pretense of using John Patrick Lowrie's voice, he's not even in intro with lines from Kickstarter campaign like the last time, what a lie that all was...

No wonder Uber tried to release it again under slightly different name to get rid of all deserved negative reviews from buyers and media... What? 'Mindestens, you crazy git, this couldn't be one of factors!' Well, they're panning some negative feedback on forums about Titans already because they don't like customers who are not writing paeans. Pointing out all the shady things doesn't help pushing more copies of the same product it was last year, it seems. But now it has a couple more units! Ugh. You couldn't even save during mission for months after release or run it offline, or use features/units promised. Pathfinding is still shaky. Ordering building construction doesn't create it's unfinished skeleton until worker/commander actually gets there and starts making the thing so you can't add idle units to construction of queued buildings ahead in the meantime. I wouldn't mind having some sort of indicator where I ordered units to gather after construction. Interface is still lacking. Tutorials are a joke (but earlier there wasn't any). To think this patch deserves any money is just bonkers or symptome of Stokholm syndrome.

People were screwed over by Uber and their pals Nordic Games back then, some even realised that - of course they're angry. And now they are screwed over again because unless you were <strike>dumb enough like me to trust these hacks over three years ago with money</strike> Kickstarter backer, you ain't gonna get this glorified patch! But if you got their unfinished borked product earlier, you get 66% discount on your patch. Off you go, sucker!

And all that not even a year after initial release. Hope all those who sticked for multiplayer defending game like it was land of their fathers enjoy sudden fragmentation of community and extra payment to keep playing it when most people inevitably switch over.

reviewText: Update - 21/11/15 Unfinished base game with poor review score has returned to store after new rereleased  base game plus extra units - Titans" has moved past its initial launch period...\n\nOk
date: there is a lot of anger over this release and to be honest it is understandable. This game is a re-release of the original Planetary annihilation with a few extras thrown in and then sold for £29.99! (This has become quite common during these hard times just rereleasing what should have been dlc packaged with the base game and then sold for a premium price).\n\nI was torn about purchasing (supporting this practise
recommended:
see end opinion) this. I was given a 66% discount as I had already purchased the base game but even then it rankled me knowing it was basically dlc. In the end I treated it as such and got it.  Having spent a few hours trying out all the additions I can say its fairly disappointing. Everything added is what the base game needs to reach a decent state.

I feel sorry for anyone who has the base game alone as its basically unfinished. This full priced "dlc" brings the base game to a finished state and as such should have been patched in arguably for free.


Now that is out of the way... I enjoy the presentation and mechanics of the game itself. I play primarily in single player and skirmishes. Altho the Galactic war single player non campaign (just a series of skirmish matches) has been rather boring so far as in 15 odd matches the ai has not moved
hoursPlayed:
at all... It builds a few buildings then... nothing... This is on normal difficulty. It will happily stay there for hours as I build up all around it. Unfortunately my ai companion is on steroids and obliterates the non-ai every match in minutes making the whole campaign pointless so far...

It is a real shame that no effort was put into making the single player campaign more immersive. I understand that is not the intended goal but to tack on a non campaign is pitiful. I can just hit a skirmish match and get a better experience every time. Wasted opportunity. I suppose it ticks the boxes as it is present but in a most lacklustre fashion.

What this dlc brings to the base game is a lot of needed variety to the units. A handful of titan units
voteText: tutorial
helpfulPercent: bounty mode (more fluff) and slightly altered terrain (also in base game)
votesHelpful: altho in a very artificial tacked on manner. Dont expect mountains
votesTotal:
valleys or anything of the kind. Just a slightly elevated series of platforms that look like they have been pasted on. So basically a lot of extra units.


What should have happened :

Base game remains. Dlc called "Titans" added for £6.99 max. Optionally add more actual content and call it an expansion £12.99. Result - happy customers and reviews resulting in more happy customers
votesFunny:
hence more money.

Release future series of dlc/expansions. Happy customers purchase them. Look at crusader kings 2. I have spent a fortune on dlc/expansions which bring meaningful changes to the game and also by the way put 80% of the features of the dlc into the base game for free.

What happened:

Update - 21/11/15 Unfinished base game with poor review score has returned to store after new rereleased  "base game plus extra units - Titans" has moved past its initial launch period...

Base game effectively abandoned and removed from store. (cynical customers might wonder if it was to hide the poor review score. I personally recommended it. ) Dlc called "Titans" branded as standalone added for £29.99. Result - unhappy customers and negative reviews resulting in less customers. Hence less money.

Yes the money men will say if 100k buy it at £29.99 its better than 300k buying it at £6.99 in the shortterm. At the expense of reputation and goodwill. Your reaping the costs now. No amount of countering reviews will change that or removing base games or arguing adding 6 big units and 20 small ones and rebranding the game and selling it twice is a good thing.

This really grates me. This game should be massive. Instead it stalled not due to the gameplay so much as the business model and direction surrounding it which is a real real shame.


So overall:

If you own the original and dont intend to purchase this premium dlc I offer my condolences. You have effectively been abandoned. You have an unfinished game that I doubt will ever reach a finished state.

If you have not purchased the original or are contemplating doing so due to the low price
commentsCount: dont. Wait for this one to go on sale a few months down the line.\n\nI will not recommend it based on the price and the effective abandonment of the original
column16:
removing it from steam. I can not support this style of selling games.

reviewText: This is the game you should have had when they labeled PA finished. It's a great game and all, rather much like vanilla with extra units, for this reason it gets a negative review from me, crap business ethics and outright unfairness distributed throughout the community.\n\nUnfortunately, It still has all the rough edges PA has. Very poor pathfinding, even worse now with the bigger units. Very poor sometimes broken A.I. Texture sampling across the board is knackered, zooming in turns the ground into tiny triangles. It crashes all the time. It runs a lot worse than vanilla performance wise. These will probably one day all get fixed, but who knows with the way Uber work. Stick with vanilla if you already have it, otherwise wait for a hefty sale.

reviewText:
TITANS is, essentially, just DLC for the original Planetary Annihilation, posing as a standalone expansion. For a more accurate view of PA's reception please refer to its store page:

store.steampowered.com/app/233250

TITANS introduces new planets, some minor updates and a whole load of new units. However, the game is still plagued with poor enemy AI and poor pathfinding. My units are unable to work out the shortest route and sometimes simply get stuck. This is an issue that has persisted ever since the alpha, and still has not been completely tackled. While Uber has worked on these issues, they are still there.

I've also had some problems with placing buildings near walls, where the building's outline suggests the building fits and can be constructed, but my units refusing to do my bidding. Just like kids.

The biggest issue, for me, has always been the camera. Representing maps on a sphere introduces its own set of challenges, and while I don't think Uber, neccessarily, missed the ball here. I would've loved a feature where I could 'flatten' my planet, in order to create a flat 2D representation of it.

For new users, TITANS should definitely be the way to go, it represents the product - more or less - that EA and KS backers were expecting but never recieved. Luckily, KS backers can expect to receive TITANS at no additional costs. While EA backers who paid the same price as KS backers are shafted. However, anyone who owns PA before the announcement of TITANS does get a 66% discount. Regardless when you purchased PA.

For those that bought themselves into PA through KS and EA - steer clear. For those looking for a new RTS, get TITANS, as it offers the same and more content as PA.

reviewText:
I am so done with this.

Uber left the ill received classic version of PA unfinished, only to release a standalone expansion to appease it's dissatisfied kickstarter backers. According to the developers it is now a finished game. After playing PA: Classic and PA: Titans for weeks I am fully convinced it is NOT a finished game.

It is obvious Uber Entertainment mismanaged their resources to construct a worthy spiritual successor to Total Annihilation. Funding that would have been better spent to iron out creases in overall game experience was used for customized commander skins and merchandise. The end result is a buggy mess with cartoony graphics and even worse unit pathing than its predecessors.

Here is a list of some(but not all!) faults both versions of the game have:

-No factions. Everyone gets the same units and buildings.
-Very little unit variation. Only 2 tiers of tech.
-No campaign. Galactic War is a stopgap at best.
-Galactic War is no different than skirmish games. Nothing stops me from rushing and sniping the enemy commander, even without unit upgrade cards.
-There is no option to turn off defeat after commander death. Seriously, would it have killed them to add this?
-Many large units are unable to fire their weapons correctly on smaller planets.
-Unit pathing is bad to the point of being unplayable on some maps. Units will frequently get stuck in terrain or buildings.
-Incompetent AI. It knows how to spam units and thats it. Turns every game into a lagfest. Even on hardest setting it doesn't even try to defend its most important unit: the Commander.

reviewText:
This is a game about recursive robots.

You start off with a commander robot, who can fabricate fabricators. These fabricators can fabricate robots that fight for control of resources that let your fabricators fabricate better fabricators, which fabricate better robots that kill the enemy better, which gains you more resources that your better fabricators can use to construct weapons that will destroy the enemy's fabricators before they can fabricate weapons that will destroy you, stopping your fabricators from fabricating.

10/10 would fabricate again

reviewText:
Somewhat on the fence with this one. It definitely has the potential to be a good game, but clearly still needs work.

PRO:

- fast-paced gameplay
- intuitive keyboard mapping

CON:

ok so i had the first PA and today i got got this PA TITAN here is my list to help you think if this game is for you.


PRO's
- has more unit's then the first a total of 21 in fact across the tech trees.
- new maps.
- the titans.

ok that is all the pro's for this ya i no not alot is there and the pro's even come with down sides so read this and then decied.

CON's
- the new units most of the new units fit nicly into the game and can add some great tactics but there are a few that are so unbalanced that within 10min you can have them killing across the system(not planet but system) with little to no resitence due to being easly gotten early and cheaply but can hit every thing on and off world.
- the new maps they have now taken over 5 out 6 match will be repeating the same old map time and time again due to the game ai not being able to randomly pick properly.
- the AI even if you put the diffculty up you have a great chance the AI when found will not have even bother to build any thing so you just wasted your game building and construting your base and army just to find out that a couple of bots and your commander could have kill the enermy in 3min flat instead of the 30+ you just spent.
-the titans well they look good but only a couple of them have any real use and really only to defend your world the rest they arn't even worth the file space.
- BUG's well ALL the old bugs from the first PA are still here but worse.
- CRASHES ok this is the big 1 even PA 1 had crashes but few and far between but PA titans have even brought that to a whole new lvl you can crash loading the title screen you can crash slecting your name you can crash selecting your commander you can crash well i think you get the point.
- THE GAME IS NOT FINISHED ok here is the biggest con and that is that the first PA was not and no where nearly finished and even with this game with dlc it does not add much if any thing thanks to the increase in bugs and crashes and it should be taken back to EA and be given some more love to help polish and fix it.

So there you go i do love this game it has great promise but in it's current state i can not in my right mind recommend this game to be brought it is just not ready.

reviewText:
Right...Big supcom fan here. Played a lot of the original PA too.

Performance - i7-3970X, aka a 6-core, 12-CPU processor at 3.5 to 4 ghz based on need. Twin Nvidia GTX titans running in SLI. 64 gigabytes of ram. Water cooling and lots of fans to ensure maximum performance and running from an SSD.

I get 60 fps when the camera is COMPLETELY MOTIONLESS. SOMETIMES. Otherwise it dips to 20 or less. I don't want to know how it is on slower systems, and from what I've read, the result is crashing. I'm not bragging about my system here, I want you to know that the ABOVE listed specs can barely run the game despite having no issue with the base PA.

Gameplay - 2nd tier expanded to be more useful with additional units, minor 3rd tier added with things like a secondary commander or flare-launching hoverplane or orbital battleship, support for Multi-level terrain" which isn't what it sounds like - it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t preset CSG plateaus and pits that have to be manually edited in as the random generator can't handle it. New structures like the "Lob"
date: a little mini unit cannon turret that fires 9 dox at the nearby enemies periodically. Titans that are constructable and are effectivelly the experimentals from Supreme Commander. Nice additions
recommended:
worthy of an update or cheap DLC.

Tutorial. Sucks. Basically a series of massively handicapped skirmish games you would have to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to lose with tooltips for assistance.

And that's it.

Kickstarter backers get it for free. I payed $90 for the alpha and got stimped on the deluxe edition which i was a bit unsettled about

reviewText: Basically the devs though it would be a good idea to resell the game just because they fixed some bugs and added new units. What they could have done is fixed the base game and had the new units as dlc. And I've noticed that the PA: TITANS has some issues too. Titans are too easy to get very early on in the game which makes the rest of the match a cake walk (atleast vs AI since I was playing the campaing) and I'm not very good at rts games and thought normal would be a challenge for me since I'm not good at the whole macro stuff. Well turns out that the normal bots are more like passive and I ended up completeting galactic war at the second hardest difficulty with no real challenge. And I also noticed a few performance issues can't really say if it was my video card not being powerful enough but in the previous game I ran the game fine at 60 fps even with a large number of units, but in titans my fps dropped to 28 pretty soon so I put my graphics to medium but that only postponed the inevitable fps drop. And when I start the game up there is a loud white noise that last for about a second but is still very annoying.\n\nConclusion: New units are nice but feel a bit overpowered and the game performs worse then the orignal atleast for me.

reviewText: Planetary Annihilation: TITANS at its current state feels uncomplete. If you just want a game to play in your free time or to play alone with ai this is a pretty cool game. But, the multiplayer is the only reason why i got this game. The problem with multiplayer right now is that there is only a small amount of games that you can join. Even joining a lobby has tons of bugs. If you even do manage to get into a game the simulation speed will slow down by A LOT. When i mean a lot i mean a lot. Once everybody starts advancing in the game you build more robots or tanks or whatever your doing, the game itself starts to slow down to the point where its half as fast as if you where just starting. The new units add a lot more to the game but i would not recommend this game. Its too buggy at its current state. If they would fix some of the bugs then there would be more players and less of a cash grab from the original Planetary Annihilation game.

reviewText:
In a word 'Disappointing'

In many words: It is certainly a polished game, everything is slick with regards to building units and placement. I played PA when it was first out and this has come on a long way since then... and that's about the only good thing I can say about it.

This game is missing the following

- Factions, all commanders have all the same build options, no unique experimentals, *cough, I mean Titans.
- Commander Upgrades, the commander becomes pretty useless very early on. Just something you want to hide.
- Rebalancing, as soon as you get some of the later units, the earlier ones are useless.

And because of the over powered units it is so easy to win now and impossible to bunker in. I enjoyed the other Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander games as some of the bigger games became a massive grind to take the enemy and I enjoy that. Now whoever can build the biggest unit first and boom I win.

As soon as someone gets a small moon, they can one kill giant planets. Takes no time at all to build a Hallie now.
As a kickstarter (got this for free), I think Uber have ruined something that could be amazing and to charge people for this who already bought PA is a further insult.

Don't buy this game, play Supreme Commander instead.

reviewText:
Hmm uber entertainment done goofed up again.

They release this expansion" to plantery annihilation as a standalone title with a $15 upgrade tier to people who bought the game on steam or free for KS backers

What doesnt make sense is the new standalone title contains the original + the new content but they didnt release it as a simple DLC to the original base game because in their words "we felt it added more than just a DLC" but anyone could see it's really just so they could get on steam frontpage again to promote the game.

Now the messed up part is that they have said they've put through a request to valve to remove the original from sale since the new one contains all content anyway. Anyone who shelled out $90 for the game when it was in steam early access doesn't get the expansion free and since its not part of the base game
date:
it's a new seperate game that means that they have no way of playing the game with new players or anyone who deletes the old one and downloads the new one.

They shouldve just made it a DLC and a tickbox to host using dlc content or not like every RTS ever instead of re-releasing it as a new product and shafting their customers for the second time.

The first time of course charging the outrageous highest backer price of $90 for the game on Steam early access to "make it fair to KS backers" thus misunderstanding the entire concept of early access being to reward people for supporting a game in its infancy and helping to build it into a successful product whereas KS is the opposite direction of funding the initial development.

At this point you have to wonder who is making the decisions at the company
recommended: obviously not someone who has actually used Steam before that's for sure."

reviewText:
Well, I'm really disturbed by PA: TITANS...

I am a fan of PA, though RTS is not my favorite kind of game I have really enjoyed PA. The game wasn't perfect; good, but always felt unfinished.
I was waiting for a PA 2, finishing what first game had started, or at least updates for the game.

Then PA: TITANS came... The game itself is nice, giving us more ways to annihilate, more units, planets...
But what's wrong with it? TITANS is exactly what I expected of PA to begin with, including what was missing for it to be near perfect; I just didn't expect to have to buy another game for this. I have the feeling I bought PA now only to be an EA of TITANS and having to pay even more for what needed completion.

Also, now the community has been split into two parts... PA Vanilla and PA TITANS. Am I the only one who thinks it was the wrong decision to make a standalone expansion?

And I will not speak about the bugs which haven't been resolved since Vanilla, or the pathfinding which is yet to be improved... Maybe buying a new game will give us new updates to fix these issues.

Conclusion: good" game

reviewText:
<edit>
I am adressing this as an expansion, not as the original game, stating that I would not recommend buying the expansion if you already have the original.
I got the expansion for free as I backed PA very early on.

If you don't own the game and are looking for a quirky RTS following the Total Annihilation line then this game is certainly worth a look.

The following is a bit about my background with the RTS genre as well as a few of the gripes I hold towards the game.
</edit>

I herald back from the time of Total Annihilation, the RTS that got me into RTS's, a fantastic game that I would suggest it to any RTS lover who's willing to deal with the somewhat dated graphics.
I moved onto Supreme Commander, which was in essence an enjoyable evolution from TA, SupCom being great for competative and social play, with its many facets. Then came about Forged Alliance, a stand alone expansion from SupCom, which brought a new faction, SP campaign and features, whilst still holding onto the core principles that made SupCom a great and worthy successor to TA.
Then there was SupCom 2...... ok ..... that game was a massive let down, being thrown into the casual pit, it wasn't in the same boat as TA and SupCom(/FA) and although it had some interesting" things
date: it was in essence very bland.\nWhen I saw the kickstarter for Planetary Annihilation
hoursPlayed: I thought it looked like TA but being over multiple planets... large solar systems and galaxies to wage war across.... perhaps a place where large numbers of players could be part of the same galaxy
voteText: holding worlds for their respective factions/clans..... I know a man can dream right.....\nSo
helpfulPercent: I got onboard the kickstarter
votesHelpful: dreams of conquest and strategic complexity whirring through my mind....\nAs you can imagine I was a little disapointed with the initial game
votesTotal: but I thought that it could grow into the competative powerhouse I had invisioned...... I waited so long...... then TITANS.....\nThis isn't a really good RTS from a competitive standpoint.... a lot of the wow and awe moments of this game don't actually come across if you are "playing to win". Winning is easy
votesFunny: just take out the commander
commentsCount: which has been the goal of all previous games of this theme
column16: but in past games
column17: turtling up and protecting your commander was a doable task
column18: but not here... when you have intel on a commanders location is ridiculously easy to take him out as he is nothing more than a large fabricator bot.\nThe only time the commander is safe is in the first 3-4 mins of the game where his weapons are such that it can take out the small number of early units sent his way
column19: able to fend them off whilst constructing.\nWhen the game gets to min 5 however it all changes....\nDepending on your build strategy in the first 4 mins will determine whether you will win or lose the game and it is all based on numbers
column20: not economic number as was the case with SupCom
column21: but the number of factories you have setup and the amount of tanks you have.....\n8 early game flame tanks is all you need to kill the commander... aproaching from at least 2 vectors can almost guarantee you a win unless your opponent has also built flame tanks.\nThe risk/reward for just spamming flame tanks is so greatly in your favor that there is little point doing anything else.... heck even if they are on another world
column22: it just takes a little intel and a handful of flame tanks and even the most developed worlds won't save your commander from utter destruction.\nNo amount of defensive structures will keep you alive..... you can't turtle in PA
column23: there is only one viable strategy and that is rush and that makes this a very boring RTS
column24:
which is why I cannot recommend it.....

<edit>
Thanks to SKaREO for pointing this out.
The game is not without its complexity and resource management is cruicial if you are to succeed

reviewText:
The game is fun and you will find yourself playing it a decent bit, however there are alot of things that bother me. Not least the devs shamefull display of promising such essential things like improved naval combat and more complex planet geography in there kickstarter and then locking these features behind the paywall that is PA titans.


- Game is buggy, laggy and crashes/ freezes far more often than is acceptable. This has been a problem for a long time and doesnt seem to have been addressed in PA titans.

- Units have poor pathfinding and will get stuck behind hills and other scenery alot. Having to manually move your stuck troops around obstacles is infuriating. On multiple occasions i have discovered that my essential support units like ant- air and anti-orbital ground units have become backed up on there way to the front line and this has resulted in me losing massive swathes of my army needlessly. Titans are even worse and will hopelessly try to walk through solid cliffs and your own factorys.

- The round planets are disorientating and make it hard for you to keep track of where everything is.


If you can put up with these issues then perhaps you can find some enjoyment in the game. However i would reccomend purchasing it on sale

reviewText:
*This review is not a comparasion to the original PA. See it as if it is the final release of PA.*

*This is not a personal opinion but an informative review of what this game have to offer and its quality.*

The game :

Planetary Annihilation is a RTS of large scale with thousens of units on a planetary scale. For the first time you can *Anihilate* planets in real time to humiliate youre opponent. You can desimate youre enemy in many ways; Nuclear missiles, massive army of bots, build teleports to sneak behind their defence lines, blast a moon into theire home planet or ultimately annihilate the planet with a *death star* Unfortunately most of the time the game end before you can build such super weapons.

Gameplay :

It is classic RTS. You build a base, gather ressources; energy and matter, build an army and fight. You will have land vehicles, Bots, air units, ships, orbital units and Titans. All class with their unique abilities like: anti tank, anti air or both... You will have to make a good balance of all to succeed.

Multiplayer :

Multiplayer in PA is unique. You can make youre own custom planetary system and try endless of possibilities. There is a nice matchmaking for 1vs1 for quick battles. There is no custom setup as of disabling some unit or tech for now.

Singleplayer :

The galactic conquest offer a different gameplay compared to the regular skirmish or multiplayer. You start with basic tech *less unit* and as you conquer more systems you will get more unit/tech. There is no factions or story in the game but there is a background story in the conquest.

Score:

Gameplay: 5/10
+large scale battles
-No factions
Multiplayer: 8/10
+Many choice of strategy
Singleplayer: 1/10
-No story
Overall: 5/10
The game is unfinished, need many improvements and have no immertion. You come in and you are a commander and must to annihilate all other commander for unknown reasons. On the other hand the competitive multiplayer is something realy interesting if you have realy good hardware and good internet.

reviewText:
PLANETARY ANNIHILATION REVIEWAs much as I would love to give this game a thumbs up, due to the problems the game has, I cannot. This is a serious review for anyone looking to buy the game, as you must be warned before you purchase this for $43.99 .

PROS
great gameplay
interplanetary wars
fun and exciting
good graphics
CONS
insane fps drops
buggy AI pathing
crashes
This game, is an extremely good release to try to bring back an old age of RTS games in an age of MOBAs. I must admit, it is a good game with a very good concept and idea. Its essentially a war on four scales. Ground, Water, Air, and Space. The overall idea based behind this game is a good one, however I do not feel I am able to give this game a thumbs up yet. For now I must give it a thumbs down for numerous reasons. Reason #1. If you have a solar system with 6+ planets, the game is laggy, crashes and is just generally unreliable. I will give you my system specs just so you can understand that I don't have a below sub-par computer, and my computer should be able to run games like these well. Reason #2. This game is basically a DLC for Planetary Annihilation, they should've just added it as a purchaseable DLC instead of forcing people new to the game to drop 15$ more into purchasing it. Reason #3. Extremely buggy AI pathing.

System Specs
Intel i7 4990k Quad-Core 4.3Ghz Overclocked
Nvidia GeForce GTX 980 Graphics Card
16 GB Memory
1 TB HDD
500 GB SSD
MSI Z87 GD65 Motherboard

Back to the review. The lobby pre-game looks nice, unfortunately if the solar system is decently large it takes a while to load the system before you get in the game, its got horrid FPS, and you still have to load the system in a loading screen either way. Into the game, if you actually make it in (you have 6 or less small planets with maybe one large planet) then the game is fun, however large armies take the FPS down a lot as well. Not to mention that lots of ground troops (bots, tanks, etc.) have extremely horrible pathing. 50% of the time if you are trying to attack around a mountain, a large amount of the bots in your army will get stuck and are not able to move. However, the game is still enjoyable, it gives a fresh new taste to Planetary Annihilation as its own standalone game, but if you we're looking to purchase this if you have vanilla PA or are looking to get either of them, stick with the vanilla version as there are not enough new units and such to make this a decent buy. Even for $14.96 it's still a bit pricey.

TL;DR It's a fun game, but has FPS problems and crashes frequently, would not recommend, buy vanilla PA

Overall Rating 4/10

EDIT: I have been notified that you are no longer able to purchase vanilla planetary annihilation, this honestly infuriates me because this costs 15$ extra, and should just be DLC. Another cash grab I suppose.


PS, Sorry for bad english, and errors

reviewText:
I found this game to be marginally entertaining at best and in no way worth the full price.  However, that is a subjective criticism based on my own criteria for what makes a worthwhile RTS.  So, I'll try to break it down Barney style using less subjective observations and let reader decide if this is a game worthy of a place in their library.

The Good:

- A multitude of units to build.
- There are many methods at the players disposal to destroy the enemy (nukes, zerg tactics, celestial collision, etc.)
- Scale of environment and units is impressively broad.
- Many unlocks and buffs in campaign mode.
- Graphics and animations are good.
- Ample amounts of action and explosions.
- Simple, easy to learn gameplay.
- Voice dubbing was tasteful for an indie developer.

The Bad:

- Expensive (real money) reskins of the commander unit.
- Overhyped game.
- A critical lack of immersion.
- Building an army becomes a chore very quickly.
- Game crashes on the regular.
- Game desynchronizes on the regular.
- Why is this game so buggy?
- Questionable Ethics of the development team.

The Grey:

- Everything is expendable.
- Simple & unimaginative resource gathering system.
- Simple story and plot.
- A thousand ways to achieve one outcome; 'Annihilation.'
- Music is creatively repetitive.
- The music.
- Rounds are over very quickly most of the time.

In short, this game does what it was meant to do very well- be an easy to play sandbox of creative destruction on an unparalleled scale for the casual RTS enthusiest.  Unfortunately, I cant recommend that readers make a full price purchase of this game until Uber tackles the bugs that riddle PA.

It adds new units and ELEVATION. They're marketing elevation in an RTS. Good ♥♥♥♥ing job ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.

The new units don't matter because a lot of them you don't even get to use. I'm pretty sure that after 13 hours of play doing numerous Galactic Wars I still don't know about a lot of them. As far as I know the only unit they added was the ♥♥♥♥ing Lob which basically just wins the game for you.

And let's talk about Galactic Wars. Instead of a campaign, you get to do a bunch of missions in a row, like a fighting game. Every mission you get to pick up new tech... unless your tech slots are full. So if your tech slots are full and you've got a bunch of ♥♥♥♥ that you like and that one other thing you like is up there and there isn't a slot addon before that selection you're ♥♥♥♥ed. You just wasted like twenty ♥♥♥♥ing minutes.

And to add on one of the things you can get as a tech is a Support Commander. Literally a hard AI that gates in with you. So you get like 8 of those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, start a mission, and go get a ♥♥♥♥ing drink. Fun game, guys.

If your computer isn't beastly (Mine isn't that good but at this point I think I could make Crysis run on a ♥♥♥♥ing graphic calculator) the game will crash like a ♥♥♥♥♥, black screen, etc.

And let's not forget the fact that this is after the disgrace of Supreme Commander 2. The franchise is dead now. They killed SupCom and now they killed Total Annihilation.




So what if I really like this game?"

Go buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance and install Forged Alliance Forever off of the internet. It gives you pretty much the only REALLY unique thing this game has to offer.


"

reviewText: Planetary Annihilation was an awesome game.  It really peeked my intrest and made me want to play it.  So I caved and dug into my piggy bank.  Got my hard earned money and deposited into the devloper's pockets.  Got the game and had a fun time.  It was beta, and they promised more from the game, and a wonderful experience to come.  Patches later I saw a new thing.  Titans!  An expantion pack that changed the whole game!  New updates that where not going to be in the other game, because Titans was a completely seperate game it turned out.  Titans was not an expantion but a whole new game that... isn't the same thing as planetary annihilation?  Ok... They wanted to be like Supreme commander and do an entire expantion remake, that makes sense... what did they add?  A new faction?  No... no... same faction...  New maps?  No... no... You could create your own or just use some random premade ones.  Oh oh!  New units?  Oh... that was supposed to be in there from the beginning?  Then why did I pay for an incomplete game only to have to buy the expantion for a few new units and nothing else?  Supreme commander Forged alliance at least gave us a new campain, new units, and a completely new faction that turned it into a masterpiece of RTS games.  This... gave us what it promised and asked us to pay for more.  And in the end I still have more hours played on Supreme commander than this game... I wonder if the lack of story... lack of factions... and over hype this game got was a good thing?  It surely wasn't a good thing for my wallet.  Do yourself a favor.  Pick up supreme commander and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance (I do believe you need both) and search FA Forever into google.  Join the FREE community and enjoy a well balanced game with friends who want a casual, yet competetive game that has brought me endless enjoyment.\n\n5/10 would not play a rip off again.

reviewText:
While a game that is fun and has some fun additions there are still fundamental problems that have not been addressed



mainly the poor optimisation is the biggest problem, as your game goes on and you need a bigger and bigger force  untill you are getting 1 fps and it becomes unplayable. and there are still key balance issues.
the most effective way of defending becomes spamming orbital weapons and turrets, and when I was playing with my friend he had a gas giant and that was his key advantage as he had every space filled with defence turrets and mining rigs that gave his econ a boost that I did not have, so I sent some orbital craft around 300 to attack it and they all died upon landing and only took out 3 or 4 mining rigs so I needed something more powerful, so I chose to build a flotilla of the big powerful orbital ships and they landed without taking to much damage, I quickly prioritized his attack craft and destroyed them all easily. then they went on destroying his mining rigs

and one by one my craft started exploding, I had no clue what was causing it untill I realised that they had a low enough range to take exploding damage from the rigs.
so there was no way without sacrificing 100's of big ships to take it all over.

reviewText:
Before You read on this is a Warning Review, I enjoyed the First Planetary Annihilation very well and with a Sale, i thought i give his a try. Heres my experince that forced me to write the Review at .2 hours of gameplay.

The good thing i saw up to a point was the nice new graphics, shiny like the first, the makers did a great job at their art for a game with so much fowerpower. (Grated i only saw parts of the combat.) Not onwly that, but the new UI is nice and clean. Unlike the the last game this UI Has more to it without too much clutter, aswell as some new looks to Unit Grouping so I am happy with that bit.

Now the Problem, I recomend buying this game at sale if able cause this is sort of shotty, im not sure if its Windows 10 thats making the game Crash for me on many occassions but its kind of annoying. At the start of my game i get this weird loud sound blowing hrough my headset, after a while in game (im playing the tutorial, only on part 2 sadly) i also would get slight freezes and a black screen for a split second. After about maybe 5 Minutes max my game simply crashes.

Im a little dissapointed in how bad the game is currently for my person, while i would love to give it a thumbs up i also noticed via the discusion page that the creators are sort of deleting reviews. I want them to know that this game NEEDS to be fixed in anyway they can as the constant crashes in the Tutorial alone are enough to bring cause of conserned.

Please dont buy this game at full price but if you can get it at a deal then give it a shot, just dont be suprised if your experience is anything like mine.

reviewText: Plannetary Annihilation was already bad enough with all the bugs and distortions. This is even worse. My Saved game gets lost, my units get clogged (not narrowed CLOGGED) when they try going throught the bridge on the planet cracker, there is no way to lower the game graphics, and they have made no improvements from the last game, but yet they put a giant unit in the game that will almost make any weak laptop crash. ♥♥♥♥ING BRILIANT IDEA! It's like if someone was creating the greatest masterpiece mankind has ever seen, but then just throwing it into the gutter like a piece of poop! I really want to support this game, but the direction of the game has let me down.\n\nAs an RTS player Iove playing games like Starcraft, Dawn of War, and Age of Empires. I love being the sucker that's in command of a whole entire death army, but in order to make a good RTS game it needs to have quick access to units and not be so slow either. I know they have control groups but I'm talking about game speed wise. My computer can run 60 fps on Starcraft medium settings. With 176 zerglings on one screen attacking. If my computer can handle that then I'm pretty sure it should be able to handle PA Titans on a low setting without crashing.

reviewText: As much as I loved Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander, I can't bring myself to love Planetary Annihilation. More often than not, I end up self-destructing my commander out of frustration rather than actually finishing games. I love the units, design, soundtrack, and basically everything else; but the unit a.i. is SO FREAKING stupid. If you want your units to be able to kill anything at all, you have to micro the crap out of them. reviewText:
Titans should have been a free update, or at the very least a $5 DLC, not a full-priced game.  The new additions are nice.  Unfortunately, my previous difficulties with PA were not addressed: lack of supporting UI.  Simply put, PA is missing some critical components to UI that are required to make a game like this work (or honestly, any RTS).  I bought Titans hoping that they were.

What's wrong: There's NO MINIMAP.  Additionally, you're on a rotating globe with no visual identification as to where you are on that globe.  Where was your base?  Just pan around until you find it again.  Oh, the enemy is attacking on the other side of the planet?  Would be nice to know if that was a scout or a full-fledged invasion.  Important details :).  And that's just for a single planet.  Some maps have 6, and there's no UI information about which planets you even have troops on.  I love the idea of the game, and my friends and I gave it an honest shot with quite a few multiplayer games together.  Unfortunately, we all agreed that the UI just does not allow/support the gameplay, and the result is frustration.

Periodically I check the recent updates to see if there are any notes about improving the UI.  Nope.  I'll keep checking back, because I want to play this game, but they just don't come.  Frustrating death to such a great game concept for us.

reviewText:
My biggest issue with the game now is the difficulty jump.  On normal the enemy does nothing at all to challenge you.  They build a nice base and wait for you to attack.
On hard they're SO agressive there's Nothing you seem to be able to do to hold off their attacks.  This feels like what'd I'd call the impossible setting.
Months have gone past and Uber hasn't done anything to smooth out this difficulty curve and that's really disapointing.  I still see potential in this game, but I'm not seeing it come to light.
There are also a few bugs that seem to slow the game down after a few matches; and I think the game tries rendering all the planets at the same time but I can't be oo sure about that.
A cinematic camera for major attacks would also be appreciated.  As it is, coliding planets and other super weapons are difficult to watch.  (A warning that a super weapon's activation will kill your own hero is also needed.  Sometimes coliding planets creates a crater, sometimes both planets explode.)

reviewText:
I played and enjoyed PA classic, so I also enjoy this game. Fundamentally, there is very little difference. You have a commander with which you build factories that build combat units. Send those to kill the opponents commander and protect yours, last man standing wins! Unlike PA classic, PA Titans includes the (spoiler!) Titan class of robot. Giant machines with unique attacks, massive armor and deal more damage than a nuke.
I wish the different commanders had different abilities or there were factions to choose from with unique units. Or that you could use enough nukes to create craters in the surface of a planet. But those small gripes aside, the game is great.

Destroy the enemy by forcing planets to alter orbit, with planets that shoot lasers, by overwhelming nuclear destruction, or massive fleets of robots.

Controls - Fairly standard for RTS games
Graphics - While zoomed out they're nothing impressive, zoomed fully in you can see decent detail, but it's difficult to play the game while in so close. They aren't fantastic graphics, so you aren't missing much.
Gameplay - Don't expect much of a story. While they have framework for lore with interesting potential and the single player has fun flavor text, there's no storyline. Build, blast, blow up.

reviewText:
I was close to recommending this game, but then I realized I can only recommend it, when the price is as low as it is currently (11,09€ at 70% off). Since this review will stand longer than the sale I should give an honest opinion.

I don't know anything about the dev issues or the former game, I was also not a kickstarter participant. My friends and I found this game, thought it looked interesting and it was on sale, so we got it (thanks Jason!).
So this is an unbiased opinion, not from the view of someone slighted by the Uber devs.

For a lower price, this game is fun. Moving the units about, building stuff and the planet hopping is quite entertaining and the RTS elements themselves are semi-solid.
The game would not be worth the original price though.

Pros:
- Multiplayer RTS game with AI, what else can you want. It should be standard these days, but with indie developers, you often find it isn't.
- Quite a lot of different units, buildings and things to do.
- The planet hopping is done interestingly and well.
- Instead of micro management, this game is more set to macro combat, a concept I quite like.
- The game utilizes a window-in-window kind of news system, where you can easily and quickly see trouble, problems and points of interest.


But now the sad parts, some of them game breaking when you forget them.

Cons:
- Some units are downright useless, even if you spend a majority of your resources on them. A good example are the highest orbital ships you can build. With just the tiniest bit of micro management, a few smaller ships or even a few ground units can, for some stupid reason, kill your entire fleet. Yes, the ships can be helpful in a big war, however they can easily be caught unaware since they're so slow.
- In conjunction with the previous con, the army movements are... lacking. A simple command like moving as slow as the slower member of your army is not easily found, the pathing is... weird... (sometimes a ship can't fly over debris??).
- The AI difficulty curve is STEEP. A Normal" AI won't even fight back much
date: you can annihilate them with pretty much a single unit (a titan or a commander building the Annihilazor on a metal planet

reviewText:
Product received for free

For full disclosure I may KS Backer and I use the Uber Launcher not Steam. So the hours I've played are not visible.

The game is highly moddable but lacks audio modding capabilities for undisclosed reasons barring  this it is very moddable. There is an mod called Legion[exodusesports.com] and it adds complete new faction to the game. Thank you to all the hard working mod developers. The newest patch has a built in mod manager. Active modding community and I find them helpful. So if you like modding feel free to jump in.

Gameplay it plays like a faster paced version of Total Annihilation. It doesn't allow you to turtle which removes some of the depth in the game. Unlike Total Annihilation you can't use small amount of units it is either large or nothing.  And some aspects of Supreme Commander mainly experimental. It has a unique orbital gameplay mainly delegated to the defense layer. The maps around causing you to defend all sides of your base and allowing for greater attack surface.

PA:C and PA:T our cheat/hack resistant for example map hacks is simply impossible due to client server architecture of the game. The server never give the information required to do hack to the client. That is one example of how cheats or hacks are prevented.

With every Titans includes PA classic; you can play Titans and Classic games in the lobby and even play on classic ladder. you can do this by switching the game product in settings to Classic or Titans. Titan games are labeled in the multiplayer lobby. Or you can play skirmish gives the AI and Galactic war.

Titans includes new experimental units called Titans. They are massive and cost a lot of metal to build. There considered Game Ender units. Wreckage is now in PA making it more like Total Annihilation allowing for defensive use of wreckage. There is a new game mode called bounty where the last person to destroy the enemy commander gets a income bonus to their economy. It was designed for Free For All to stop turtling and hiding from people. there are new units and structures as well as improvements across the board.

Personally dislike the fact that it is a standalone expansion not a regular one and everybody wasn't required to buy it. But I respect Uber for this decision on it and I can see where they're coming from. this expansion definitely needed a new separate faction but never got to see one which makes me sad. it lacks a fully scripted campaign mode which is a pity if you like that kind of stuff like I do. The complete lack of 4K support is a shame but there is a workaround and it's playable but not future proof. Commanders are boring and would add an element of depth if they had special abilities.

Pros   Cheat and hack resistant
Highly moddable
In-game mod manager
PA classic included
Titans (experimental)
Unit wreckage
A new game mode
New units
More improvements
Cons   Lack of audio modding[forums.uberent.com]
Standalone expansion
No fully scripted campaign mode
Commanders lack special abilities[forums.uberent.com]
No new separate faction
Lack of 4K support[wiki.palobby.com]
Overview of the Community Update build# 94684      In-game mod manager
Custom Server support
Server improvements
New modding capabilities
Numerous UI enhancements
Tons of bug fixes
Special thanks to all who worked on this build especially pinbender, mikeyh, wondible. For full patch notes go here:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/386070/discussions/0/357287304440976398/

reviewText:
If the devs give this game workshop support then the game might just rise from the dust. Sadly I doubt that will be the case as Uber hasn't updated it for many months now.

TL:DR - The game is really fun, especially with friends. But Uber sucks as a company and has probably abandoned the game by now. It's a sad waste of potential.

The negative reviews for this game are 90% people who are angry about Uber basically releasing the game a second time at full price for a package that was really just some DLC plus the base game. Quite the scummy move, Uber.
However despite Uber's poor business plans, the game itself is quite fun especially with a few friends. There's nothing quite like fielding a massive army, then only using it to secure a death star to blow up every other planet in the system. The score for this game is fantastic, it sounds very massive and epic and when you hear it while your army crushes the opposition, it gives you the chills that only something this awesome can bring.

On the negative side, there's really very little optimization (if any) and as I mentioned above, I think uber has just given up on keeping this game up to date.
I hope some responsible companty buys the rights to this game, because there's really a lot of potential here, especially for player-made content considering the style of the units and buildings.

reviewText: Love this game, almost much as I love what this game is striving to be. As a spiritual successor to Total Annihilation, this game gets much right, however similar to TA and Supreme Commander that followed, its ambitions far exceed its development budget and computational capacity for the time in which it was released. I can only hope similar to TA/SC, that future PC hardware will allow this game to be played at the scale it was envisaged. A poorly handled release and then re-release gave birth to many grumpy and vocal supporters, however the end product taken completely at face value is really a fantastic but flawed classic. If you are looking for your large scale RTS fix, and are tolerant of a few rough edges, then this should be great value. Do yourself a favour and look for PAMM (PA Mod Manager) and read up on many mods which help to smooth over a lot of User Interface and Gameplay quirks which the developers have never (and probably never will) had the opportunity to remedy. I backed this game heavily in the original Kickstarter, and whilst I often wonder how much much it could have turned out, I have no regrets at all.

reviewText:
Highly Recommended...

Although I only haven't played a ridiculous amount of time on this game I have to say it is up there with some of my favourite title's. The game has had it's fair share of negative review's which tend to be soley based on the fact that the developer's are supposidly 'greedy' and are not the best dev's that you can hope to find.

In my opinion it is unfair to judge and review a game based on it's developer's and infact we should be reviewing this game based on it's content and quality of design. Personally I have to say this game's graphic's are far more beautiful than a large range of title's out there on the market. And regardless of it being an RTS the graphic's upclose are great. This game feature's many unit's that add a huge range of diversity to it's combat and strategy, and ensure a different experience every time you play. In my time played I have not noticed any bug's or glitches and would say this game is most definitley polished. This game provides a great take on combat and really give's it's users the ability to mix and match on the battlefield.

In my opinion this is a great game and I would highly recommend it to anyone with a love for RTS game's and for anyone who is willing to sacrifice their time to experience the sheer beauty of this game and all it has to offer.

10/10, Great Quality, Great Combat, Enjoyable Experience

reviewText:
Oh, look. It's the game we were promised. It's too bad we have to buy the game again in order to get it.

What's funny is that this feels like the beta version of the game originally promised. Clunkiness in the interface was never fixed, in fact it's made worse in several respects with overlapping popups and immovable popout windows.

If this were released as Planetary Annihilation 1.0, this would be one of the best RTS games on the store. That's the real tragedy of it all. It's a game that has released the finish product as an expansion to a game they never finished, and it STILL has glaring usability problems and clunky controls.

Want my advice? Save your money and buy Grey Goo instead if you're looking for an RTS or if someone reads this on the cusp of a steam sale.

Waiting patiently for the day we get our refund for PA's base game, which can no longer be bought or played online as this supplants it in every way, shape, and form. I will likely be waiting a very, very, very long time.

reviewText:
Hey everyone,

A little background: I had PA since the alpha stage. I chose to move to PA Titans with the special offer for 10 bucks. I do have and play SC2.

I have read some of the reviews, and I agree that, maybe, dev wanted to make some money out of the Titan “expansion”.

Now, I believe that some of you got the wrong idea of this “strategy” game. Most of the strategy games work with a balance of attack and defense, true. PA is a strategy game where I see Attack as the only key of the game. There is NO DEFENSE here.
Let’s have a look at another game, SC2. Some of you have mentioned that would gladly go back to play SC2, and I understand that -- I love SC2. But these two games are completely different. See, SC2 has a great deal of “defense”. If you push the AI to very high difficulty and they are located in a floating island, you can’t really get to them. At the same time you can spend 30 min building your own defenses, and you would know that you are secure under your shield generators and turrets for the next two (human) hours.

PA is nothing like that. There are no shield generators, and buildings such as turrets are destroyed very easily. There is most probably very little defensive strategy programmed in the AI. The game is all about how fast you are to build and destroy the other. It may come to a surprise to you, but it’s called Planetary ANNIHILATION.
Here comes the fun part. If you think that it is too easy for you, just create your own planetary system, set it up as you like. Then play alone against 5 AI! You can also set your own strategy to ANNIHILATE other commanders! :D

5 AI, which means that you could destroy each of them in a different way:
You build a Ragnarok on one of their planets, and annihilate the hell out of that commander!
Get on an asteroid, build halley engines, and shoot it right in the face of a commander! Guess he wasn’t expecting that.
Build 15 nuclear launchers, and nuke the hell out of another commander. Mass nuke attack on different areas of a planet! BOOM
Build 150 little exploding spiders bots, then build Helios (the titan space transporter for invasion). Connect it with a teleport. Move Helios on the other planet. Send your exploding spiders over. FRAGMENTED ANNIHILATION!
Win like a boss – Star Wars style. Get on the metal planet. Conquer it and build catalysts. Destroy the last planet in Start Wars style “Death Star”. COMPLETE ANNIHILATION!The game is really fun to play. It’s not a game that would last long (like SC2) unless you decide to. Against 1 AI you could win in 10 min, sometimes in 3 min if you are fast enough.
For who is interested in purchasing this game, consider this as a VERY fast-paced game. Within the first minutes, your fabricators will already be half the way around the planet building mass extractors. 2 min in you will have multiple factories building an army. 4 minutes in you will already have a nice army (HUNDREDs of units) and will be building the advanced factory. 7 minutes in you may already have advanced builders and would be start building advanced technology (such as the cool titans). Compare this to the slow-paced SC2, and you will understand why some people are not comfortable with it.

Finally, everything depends on you. Do you like long games? Select harder AI and more AIs. Do you want to build titans? Well, one is normally enough to ANNIHINLATE your enemy! You need more enemies to have more fun! ;D

Side note: Someone said that Galactic War is the same as Skirmish. That’s false -- Galactic War is different from Skirmish. A normal battle in Galactic War is you against one opponent. Only if you start fighting the faction commander (“mini boss”), you will find yourself against multiple enemies. When you start you will NOT have all the technology – you need to destroy other commanders to find technology (usually, when you start, you can ONLY build base vehicles). Additionally, there is some special technology which is not available in skirmish, such as 50% off production costs for Titans, 75% off energy for artillery, faster commander, faster (type) of units, faster building, stronger units, and way more! You can even find other “remains” of commanders that you can activate to have an allied AI with you in the battles. You will start with nothing, and you can end up with the most powerful combination for a TOTAL ANNIHILATION!

Enjoy.

reviewText:
I like it. I found this for a steal on Bundlestars.com ($9.99 +$1.00). The Total Annihilation feeling is also there for those who still reminisce about the good old 1997 Cavedog game called Total Annihilation. I was just wondering, where is the D-gun? The general feeling about the game is that the developers went into boring mode story-wise but got much of gameplay mechanics right. Gameplay > Lore, right? It can't get max points but it's definitely a play in my book.

PROS
1. Big Bots
The most attractive thing about this game are the big walking tin cans. Who doesn't want a mega Gundam?

2. Interplanetary Combat
Truly one of the highlights of the game.

3. The Annihilazer
Loved it. Build 5 Catalysts to activate the ENTIRE METAL PLANET and fire a beam to destroy any other planet. It warms my heart to know that I can build a Death Star without starting from scratch.

4. Titans
Super Area-of-Effect attacks. Fantastic.

CONS
1. No Impact
Shooting peas and lasers just don't simulate major combat. What I'm talking is the big vlada-boom from firing from a tank. The units don't have the oomph" when they shoot. It feels like shooting peas at each other.

2. Too Many Units to Micro
You can build over 100 units and it's a hell of a problem to manage.

3. Rotating Views of the Planets
It's difficult to comb/scout the planet as you're trying to search the surface area of a sphere. The good thing is that scout planes are cheap and radar coverage is huge.

4. Orbital Transport
Due to the Astraeus' single unit limit
date:
it is a chore to move units from 1 planet to another. It would be far better for the Astraeus to have multiple troop transport capabilities or to combine it with a teleporter.

5. 1 Capital Ship?
Only robots and 1 Capital Ship. There's a kind of limitation here. There is an Omega orbital ship but that's really limited. The defense satellites don't count.

6. Building over Ore Dots
I built an Air Factory over the Ore Dots and the next thing you know
recommended:
you couldn't build an ore extractor over it.

7. Campaign
Very dull. Move from point A to point B
hoursPlayed:
play a skirmish. There isn't a campaign at all. It's just skirmish after skirmish. I completed each map is less than 20 minutes.

8. Teleporter Facing
You have only 1 entrance to the Teleporter. The orientation is extremely important if you don't want your troops taking an additonal 5 seconds to get into the Teleporter.

9. View Orientation
A sphere with fog of war is really hard to focus on. If not for the large radar
voteText:
it would be near impossible to locate your enemies.

10. Orbitals
It's quite hard to keep track of your orbitals. All you have is a thin line that shows you where your satellite is. It's like a balloon where you only focus on the string.

11. Naval
WTF is this for? You need water? Who the hell cares?

NEUTRAL
1. Singularity Commanders
You hedge everything on 1 single commander. This is not diversifying your risk very well. While I enjoy the quickness that games will end
helpfulPercent:
I note that the same could also happen to me.

2. Ore Dots
Surprisingly
votesHelpful: this is a great idea. However
votesTotal:
I would prefer to reduce the number of dots by at least half and increase the metal production by x2 on each dot. I do not enjoy having to play Bob-the-Builder for resource structures.

3. Commander Loadouts
Good idea but executed poorly. It is most boring to see Air
votesFunny:
Orbital or Vehicle Commanders. I would suggest looking at Company of Heroes 2 for a good example of how to have commander loadouts.

SUGGESTIONS
1. Bring in Space Combat
I was hoping for Battle Cruisers
commentsCount: Capital Ships
column16:
Warp Jumps and Orbital Bombardments. The Omega is not sufficient.

2. Big Boom Units
Just like how the commander goes nuclear when he dies. Perhaps some units that will cause a mushroom cloud explosion
column17: a crater
column18: earth split
column19:
shockwave or a void hole.

3. Upgrading the Factories
A Tier 1 factory is always stuck at Tier 1. I would allow a Tier 1 to upgrade into a Tier 2 Factory so that all the factories are the same and you don't waste space. Tier 2 Factories are not unique and still produce Tier 1 units either way
column20:
so upgrading is definitely a good idea.

4. 1 Large Planet
Instead of a tiny planet
column21:
how about 1 gigantic planet to fight on?

5. Energy Shields
I would have enjoyed looking at an energy shield dome.

6. Terrain & Weather
Not sure if you can render snow
column22:
electromagnetic clouds and desert sand storms.

7. Orbitals
Turn them into autonomous drones. It is extremely tedious to have to micro 3 separate levels. Level 1
column23: planet surface\nLevel 2
column24: orbital\nLevel 3
column25: planetary\n\nIf they are drones
column26: you can actually make them orbit instead of being geostationary."

reviewText:
The figures above are not right! I've played hundreds of hours on this game usually through PAMM. It is basically the only game that I play nowadays and I have a large library of games. Also I only play single player against the AI, too many people keep saying that it is a multi-player only rts game, it is not. I have found the skirmish mode to be a lot of fun with so much to do while playing it and I always play it on absurb difficulty. There are a ton of mods to use, from AI mods to eye candy mods to map mods etc. there is also a mod on it's way for another faction. Though I don't play online there is a great community that do and most of them are very helpful if you need help with anything. My favourite game was TA but now PA is my favourite. There is a learning curve at least for me and I'm still learning, what with planets being round and not flat (makes the game very interisting when you get used to it), unit cannons, nuclear missiles, planet smashing, titans, annihilaser, asteroids, unlimited units (I think there might be a limit of 3000 but I'm not sure, if there is it can be changed in the ai_config.json using any text editor), four layers of units (land, sea, air and space) and so much more. No two games ever seem the same to me, you can play on just one planet or several, with or without moons. For me PA is very stable, and it saves and resumes ok so that I can play the long games that I like. I should also mention that you can rewind the game you are playing and start from the position you rewound to, so it is like one continuous save. If you like playing skirmish games such as TA, C&C Generals etc. then you should like PA. I don't miss not having a campaign as I don't usually play campaigns and as I mentioned before, I don't play online very often so I can't coment on them. I don't play Galatic War either (maybe I will give it a go at a later time) so I can't comment on that. But the skirmish mode keeps me entertained for ages and as far as I am concerned that is what a game should do.

i7-3770k

G skill Ripjaws-X 32G Kit (8x4) DDR3 1600
Gigabyte AMD Radeon HD 7870 2 Gigs Ram
Windows 7 Ultimate 64 bit

reviewText: Okay. So, the game is fun yes, and I think this is the only game that allows you to build giant god damned engines on a planet and fire it into another to obliterate someone, its the most satisfying feeling seeing a moon slam into a planet and the fireworks start. The visuals are wonderful, its incredibly pretty and has a great asthetic I love it and the sounds of the weapons are wonderful and firing units from planet to planet with a giant cannon is just so much fun.\n\nBut I was expecting more. Just one 'faction' no real differences between commanders aside just a aesthetic change, and the general victory condition is build engine on moon/asteroid, fire into planet, win. It may be an old game but Supreme Commander is still a far superiour game to this and honestly its better to just buy that if you want huge scale war with factions that play differently, and certainly makes you seriously fight for your victory.

reviewText:
I grew up playing CnC on DOS and all the following CnC games until CnC Generals.

When I first saw the concept of PA my inner child was so excited. Played from the Alpha all the way to full release, it has gone through a lot of tweaks over that time. Now with the release of PA: Titans I would say everything about this game is now perfect.

Although it is much harder than most other strategy games due to being on multiple planets and the amount of structures and units available it can be confusing for a first time player. But this complexity keeps the game interesting.

Also a perfect LAN game, had to be one of the best LANs because of this game. You can form alliances with friends and then turn around and back stab them all while in game. We had the best moments in LAN because of this mechanic.

The only thing this game is missing is multi-Screen displays.

reviewText:
Let's first start off as its execution. Although there are a lot of talk about bugs and such, I don't get that many groundbreaking mishaps. The only thing that consitintely annoy you is the sometimes illogical unit pathfinding. Units will sometimes take a long path, ignore your initial orders, or just do ♥♥♥♥ about one every five games. This is'nt game breaking as it only requires to reselect the units but you'll learn to get used to it.

As for graphics quality, it looks amazing but doesn't betray the artsyle it comes with. You will come to appreciate the ammount of art that went into the game.

Unit balance is good, and each unit clearly has it's own set of niches while more advance units will generally fill a single nich extremely well. Allowing unit knowledge to turn the tides.




This game is going to a blast for you if you enjoy the macro unit onslaught, a more offensive based RTS, easy to use micro-managing, and huge epic battles

reviewText: Supreme Commander is beloved RTS game with a thriving community even to this day. This game has lots of similarities to SCOM. It has the same economic system, instead of Mass, you have metal and energy. It works the same way like SCOM, you have a meter that has a certain number and as you build that number gets smaller until you build more Metal Exractors. Besides that, there is also the single unit mechainic (which means that one singular unit is made in one time) which is not my favriote unless the game makes it balanced. While there is no campaighn, you do have Galactic War which is a much longer gamemode than skirmish. Also this game allows you to have lots and lots of big battles. Back in SCOM if you were to have too many A.I's duking it out untill the very end the game would get very slow and laggy, but in this game you can have 10 players and still run the game smoothly. Also, annihilating a planet is pretty darn fun. Overall this game is great for SCOM players who want a much more destructive game

reviewText:
I grew up playing CnC on DOS and all the following CnC games until CnC Generals.

When I first saw the concept of PA my inner child was so excited. Played from the Alpha all the way to full release, it has gone through a lot of tweaks over that time. Now with the release of PA: Titans I would say everything about this game is now perfect.

Although it is much harder than most other strategy games due to being on multiple planets and the amount of structures and units available it can be confusing for a first time player. But this complexity keeps the game interesting.

Also a perfect LAN game, had to be one of the best LANs because of this game. You can form alliances with friends and then turn around and back stab them all while in game. We had the best moments in LAN because of this mechanic.

The only thing this game is missing is multi-Screen displays.

reviewText:
Planetary Anihalation was very disappointing for people like myself that backed it very early on to the tune of 80-100 Euros.   It wasnt terrible but it was shallow and dramatically lacking in any content.

It overshot the kickstarter then never really delivered.  So, what did the developers do? Release the same product, with a bit of extra content and a new name as a new product.  Yes, they will claim they did make this clear.  So, if I take your money on the basis of a share in the return (that being a half decent game on the premis speculated, then take your (and everyone else's) collective investment and ignore that you funded the development but go on to relaunch the same game with a minor expansion as an entirely new product, that doesnt get kickstarter (and backers) foaming at the mouth? So, what exactly does it take?

Lesson learned, next week I am selling some amazing investment opportunities in the form of magical unit trusts on Kickstarter as apparently, anything goes.

This is a classic example of why I dont back games on kickstarter anymore.

Just to add insult to injury.  Saved game just disappeared.
