reviewText:
Planetary Annihilation is the latest in a family of fantastic games (except for that weird nephew who nobody likes to talk about; I'm looking at you Supreme Commander II).

I really REALLY want to like this game, I want to love it, I want it to be what Total Annihilation was, with all the good bits from Supreme Commander added in, along with some cool new stuff all it's own. Unfortunately, it just wasn't meant to be.

While it has some really cool features, like slamming asteroids into planets with massive, world-shattering explosions, or just vaporising planets with your very own Death Star, all that shiny goodness is not enough to make up for what it lacks in gameplay.
The maps are boring, and terrain features make little to no difference to your tactics. You might as well be fighting on the surface of a billiard ball. The economy, while similar to TA and SC, somehow doesn't play quite the same way, meaning that the carefull resource management that was needed in Supreme Commander is not much of a factor anymore.
Combine that with small maps that are also wrap-around, means that if you prefer to play turtle you are shooting yourself in the foot. Rushing is the only viable option, since defending your ever expanding base on all sides is all but impossible, especially since terrain features hardly offer any bottlenecks that you can use.

I love blowing up planets, I love the way the game looks, but I hate that it lacks the depth, size, and scope that TA and SC had. Battles do not feel epic because the battlefields are so small and fights are over in seconds.

As an RTS, Planetary Annihiliation is a good, perhaps even a great game. As a descendant of its ancestors, it is merely so-so. So buy it if you are looking for an RTS with inovative features and quick combat. Do not buy if you are hoping to recaputre the glory of Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander.

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game? Yes, but there is one issue that I cannot F&%KING stand and that is Commander Snipping. Commander Snipping is the act in which the enemy team discovers where your commander is and directs a quick attack against him. The easiest and most common way of doing this is by sending a fairly large group of Orbital Laser Platforms right above the commander and fire down upon them, killing the commander, and then winning the game. Understand that the commander is not a strong unit that can take a huge amount of hits before exploding. The commander is actually very weak and a small group of enemy tanks can destoy a commander if the commander does not have back-up.

I was just in a game with my friend where he and I were slowly putting the enemy team on the defensive. We had a strong economy, strong defences on our planet, and we were slowly removing the enemy from the Laser Planet. It was clear that were were the better players. What did they do? The enemy team sent a team of 5 Omegas and 20 Orbital Lasers to the general area of where they last saw my commander. I was in the process of moving my commander after their orbial radar arrived in my planet's orbit. The Commander moves stupidly slow so those 5 Omegas and 20 Orbital Lasers arrived nearly right above my commander. How long did it take for their orbital units to kill my commander? Like 5 seconds! How do you combat that? You honestly can't! It takes several seconds for Catapult attacks to arrive at their target(from the ground to space), the Umbrella's hit the target's instantly, but do not do a lot of damage, and my orbital Avengers take a second to repond to the new threat and they don't do a lot of damage individually. If the enemy tells all their orbial units to target my commander on the ground, it is game over.

This pisses me off because we were the better player's but the enemy team is able to kill ONE unit and win the game. It also annoys me that this is easily avoidable by the developement team. I remember sending the development team an E-mail in the early days of the Origainl Planetary Annihilation asking the team to provide player with the ability to choose the End Game." The first choice is that the game ends upon the Commander's death (like as it is now). The second choice is that the game ends when the Commander and every unit (excluding buildings) is destroyed by the enemy team. I received an E-mail response from them saying Thank you and that they will consider it.  Years later and they never have. We would have won the game if my forces were not destroyed and it ruined my fun.

I want to point out that I am not a sore loser when the enemy team beats me by out performing me in the game with real strategies. I become a sore loser when the enemy turns to cheap
date: easy tatics that anyone can come up with to win. To the PA developement team
recommended: please make a second "end game."\n\nNow I feel better now that I have let that out."

reviewText:
Basically a sillier, smaller, and faster paced version of sins of a solar empire. I wasn’t around for all the stuff that happened with the Kickstarter, I just bought it on a good sale. Overall, it’s worth maybe $5-10, DON’T buy it full price - get a real game instead. It is fun for a little bit, though.

Pros:
Destroying planets is quite amusing
Fast paced
Has some really cool ideas and units

Cons:
Only 3 ways to destroy a planet (gets old fast)
All sides have the same units (commanders are cosmetically different)
No real story
Map size limits are way too small for big games
AI is way, way too easy to beat
Controlling the camera takes a lot to get used to
Commanders are really easy to kill (eliminating the player)
Ridiculous micro-transactions for new commanders ($5 for a skin)
The tutorial is worthless and the important and best strategies are not obvious (I.E. workers can help buildings produce units)

So much potential, they could make a killer sequel if they really worked on it and fleshed it out better.

After a while I said to myself let's finally start on playing Planetary Annihilation since it was lying around in my Library for a while. So I also got myself the TITANS addon or whatever for 11 bugs i addition to that.

I can't play the game. It looks nice, it has a nice concept

BUT

it has bugs making the game not playable. For instance I tried to play the tutorial which crashed two times on me. Okay I thought too myself maybe Galactic Conquest will work and at least the game did not crash there

BUT

after around twenty minutes of gaming I could not select any unit with my mouse or give any command. I tried to play it a third time

BUT

I got one critical error crashing the game. So tried a last time to finish at least my first battle in the galactic conquest

BUT

again right at the beginning of the game my mouse and keyboard decided not to interact with me anymore. So I killed the game again.

I checked on the discussions and searched for the Poblem on google. It seems that I am not the only one with these issue and some people complaining about bug issues.

I can't tell if the gameplay itself is good or not because it is even not playable right now. However this is not an early access game but a fully developed and finished one. This is not acceptable and exspecially not excusable. If I buy a finished game for my money I demand that this game is playable and working. So until the issues with these bugs are not solved I would not recommend this game because right now it is just a waste of money.

reviewText:
With the type of game you would expect this to be a large scale RTS like the original Supreme Commander, this game is the opposite of Supreme Commander.

Although you may be fighting across a solar system the developers did an atrocious job of interweaving the planetary battles into the overall war. The game is fought on a planetary scale, and what you do on the planet has little effect on the overall war. You gain control of that map spot and you get to choose one of the randomly generated bonuses after each location capture.

Imagine the smallest and simplest RTS you have ever played and imagine if the developer made each skirmish so that you had to win 10+ skirmishes to win a skirmish in this game. That is what this game is. It is a tiny map with simplistic units and very little strategy. You just have to win several of those small skirmishes to win a skirmish in this poorly thought out RTS. It is nothing like what I had hoped for.

reviewText: Obviously i've only played this game for a little bit. 6.7 hours, as of this review. This game seems to be taking a lot of flak from people but it mostly sounds like its coming from people who kick started the game in early stages. I decided to try it out and i'm loving it so far, kinda reminds me of Age of Empires or Command and Conquer:Generals. So far its a game that you can enjoy playing by yourself, one of very few games i can say that about these days. It was kind of difficult getting my friend into my lobby because apparently the latest update kinda screwed up the party system with friends. You can circumvent this problem by making your custum game public and adding a password that you give to your friends so only they can join. The graphics are pretty enjoyable, i love the style that the developers chose, especially the large explosions from nukes or dying commanders. There are many different units and buildings to build, half of which i've barely explored so far. Overall, i don't have and cons of this game so far, only positives! I will update this review if i find something. 10/10

reviewText:
Have a pesky neighbour in your solar system? No problem! Just build a giant rocket on one of your moons, and fly it into their homeworld... Et voila! Not too many games I've played let you enjoy wanton destruction on this kind of scale! The artistic style of the game adds to the over-the-top weaponry to make a very enjoyable product!

This game is pretty easy to pick up, despite a lacklustre Tutorial built-in. I don't have a lot of play time yet but I can see how a single 'game' can last anywhere from 5-10m to 60+ which is great, so I can play a short game when I choose or settle in for a day of conquest!

I am not too fond of having to connect to servers and all that jazz for single-player games, on my end its just non-value-added time added to loading sequences, and a tendency to feel choppy at times because I share my connection in a rural area. (Yes, in single player I notice this- it is NOT game-breaking by any means!).

For me this is a good pickup in the $15-$20 range!

reviewText:
NOTE: Many reviews for this game are negative solely because of the developers' choices, not on the game itself. I will agree that the devs have overall cheated many people of their money, especially early backers, but that has nothing to do with the quality of the game itself. I will talk about the game only in this review.

I've put up a kind of funny review of the base game Planetary Annihilation, but it wasn't too helpful. I will make a legit review here.

What is this game exactly? This game is an RTS that takes place across a solar system. Each solar system varies, most provided in-game are only 1 planet big, but can be many planets big as well. But what does that mean? Essentially, you can start on one planet and build up your economy and an army and all that. However, with the help of orbital units, which I'll get to later, you can travel to another planet and start to expand there. This is the most unique thing about this game, in my opinion.

So, how diverse is this RTS? Not as diverse unit-wise as Supreme Commander or other RTS's, but enough to compete. There are 5 unit types: Land, Bot, Sea, Air, and Orbital. Bots are just smaller, less powerful versions of Land units, but very easy to mass-produce. Orbital units are units that, as the game stated rain death from above on units that rain death from above." Orbital units are not the best at fighting
date: but they are mainly used to gain access to other planets and other uses. The economy is essentially the same as the other well-known RTS's: Metal
recommended: to be gotten from specific metal spots on planets; and Energy
hoursPlayed: which can be generated wherever you like. The Titans are essentially the Experimentals from Supreme Commander 2
voteText: so not a whole lot to talk about there. All and all

column17: you can build 5 special structures at 5 special points to gain control of it. These special structures are even more of a pain in the butt to make
column18: but once a player gets their hands on the metal planet
column19: it's essentially game over. Or you can crash a moon into the metal planet and just not worry about it.\n\nOh yeah

reviewText: Great game. The 3D interplanetary arena is great. Units are diverse and well balanced, each with a specific role and abilities. Titans are a great to end those hour long stalemates. It has it all: planets smashing into each other, nukes, 4 layers of units: land, air, water, orbital. In-game community is very friendly, and someone is always streaming over Twitch. I also like that you can replay ANY of the matches that have ever taken place (not just yours, any players'), so you can learn from the best. Great game overall.

reviewText:
TLDR: One of the best RTS games on the market, but not a huge amount of content. Buy it on sale.

I was raised with RTS and it is a genre very close to my heart. Some of the first games I owned were Empire at War and Battle for Middle Earth. I haven't played the previous entries in the series and I didn't back the game on kickstarter.
This game is marvellous. It's a game about robots building more robots then killing other robots. The goal is to annihilate your foes, often in spectacular fashion. Crush them with a giant robot, nuke them, blow up their planet, the choice is up to you.
My one complaint is that I'm not quite sure how much content there is. There's no singleplayer campaign and the unlocking of loadouts in galactic conquest is very luck based. There also don't seem to be an enourmous number of units.
I really enjoy this game, a reasonable improvement on PA. I'd buy it on a sale though.

reviewText:
In the same way Homeworld transformed the idea of what a 3 Dimensional RTS could be, Planetary Annihilation makes a huge leap for the genre by taking RTS combat to the planetary scale.

As far as RTSs go, PA:Titans is about swarm tactics - build massive hoards of tanks / ships / jets etc and hurl them at eachother. When your economy allows, build a giant mech or ship to help push through the enemy ranks.

I would recommend this game to anyone already familiar with the RTS genre that's interested in trying out a concept that turns the idea on its ear and asks how big can a RTS be?"

There are a variety of modes and ways to play against friends and AI - there's a lot to offer here. Will it turn into the best RTS of all time? no
recommended: but I do applaud Uber for forging new ground and making us all reconsider how grand war gaming can be.\n\n~Rockanon"

reviewText:
I have read the complaints and how upset people are about kickstarter etc.  I wish people would just review or write about the game not how they feel they got ripped off by a kickstarter campaign.  Rant over..

So I purchased this during the winter sale and for $13 bucks and it has turned out to be a great game.  A really good RTS with some things that I feel are unique. The ability to destroy planets ala the Empire's star destoyer and the ability to fight on different planets in the same solar system are features that make is a fun game on the whole. Good graphics great music make this a keeper in my library.  Is it worth 3 Grande  Lattes at $3.65 each? Yes it is.  Is it worth 10 (normal price of $39.95) uh no it is not.  There are better premium classic RTS games that are actually less expensive.

Rant #2 on another note I have always felt that Kickstarter campaigns for gaming is a waste of money, A bigger waste than early access.  All you are doing is encouraging Vapor Ware.  Vapor Ware are Games that just evaporate into the ethos and never really deliver or are never really ever made.  Rant Over...

reviewText:
I've put about 25 hours into this game so far, just playing single player.  I also played all of the Total Annihilation games and Supreme Commander games so I'm pretty experienced with this game type.

The AI on the highest level is actually pretty decent and presents a reasonable challenge all things considered. It expands rapidly, and attacks aggressively, with large numbers. Which is actually better than previous games in which the computer tended to just stream units at you, rather than building large forces, even with the best mods. You usually had to let the AI cheat in previous games to get a challenge, but in this game, the AI just plays pretty well. It does seem to bottom out though with utilizing a lot of tech 2 units and mass extractors.

I'm not a big fan of the orbital concept of the game. I think it was a good idea to incorporate space faring vessels but I think it would have been better had they not been just locked into an orbit around planets, and maybe were allowed to roam freely in space. Might have made the game incredibly complex, but I think theoretically it could have been done and would have been much more interesting with proper camera control etc. But its not a big deal and the oribal units are still a positive for the game.

If you liked any of the Supreme Commander games or Total Annihilation games, you'll probably enjoy this game. Most of the negative reviews are by people who felt they were badly treated by the company that developed the game, but in the company's defense, I think they had good intentions but just didn't have enough money. Just because you contributed money to developing the game, you have to know its a risk going in that the game could flop. It's a gamble from the very beginning. They re-released the game to obviously try and save it, and I don't think they had much choice in doing so. I don't think it was their intent to cheat people.

I can understand the kickstarter's frustrations and yet its not fair to give the game a bad rating simply because you're angry at the company. I think the game should be rated on its merits purely as a game, regardless of what you think of the company, and if doing so, its a good game, and well designed.

I was not one of the kickstarters for this game and recently purchased it on sale so I can't really judge people for being angry though. I just want to give the game an honest review of the actual game.

So, to summarize, I'm very satisfied with the product. I'd recommend waiting for it to go on sale though. I'd say the game is worth about $25, but $40 is pretty steep. The game lacks a lot of elements including story etc but it does have a very simple campaign style of game where you conquer systems, and gain bonuses along the way gaining access to more units and upgrades, which is fun.

It has a few bugs still, such as the sound effects dying after a few missions, requiring a restart of the game. Overall though, it feels like Supcom but on a bit of a larger scale as you can move to other planets. Its like playing on more than one supcom map at a time if the game actually gets to that point before someone wins.

If the game had more unit diversity and more faction diversity, that could greatly improve its worth. I'm not sure if the developer is still working on this game a lot, but as it is right now, its not bad, and worth your time if you like this type of game.

reviewText:
I'm starting to see a lot of unwarranted negativity around this game. I started playing pretty early on and have been here each update. The devs have been putting a lot of work into this game since it started in early access and the updates were farely frequent and added new stuff as well as fix old stuff. This game is awesome, one of my favourite rts' even. The idea of having multiple planets in an rts has ruined me. I just wish other games incorporated scale like this. But keep in mind that this isn't an amazing rts by most people standards. The game itself is pretty simple so the only difficulty is in managing the scale of the battle. You'll be warring over planets, fighting for control over moons and the metal planet for huge tactical advantages (slamming or blasting a hole in your oponents planet). It's not easy to play but it is crazy and when you get used to it it's really fun.

Now for the controversy...

They released a dlc pack for the game which really did add a lot to the game (A lot of new units and titans mostly). But the problem (if you can call it one) is that this pack is a stand alone dlc. What that means is that if you buy the dlc, you get the entire game plus the dlc (This was the only way to get the dlc, Now you can buy the base game and the dlc is dlc)). I bought this game for about $45 on a steam sale and I got the dlc for $10. Now when you consider that I technically got a new game for $10 it really isn't a problem. Sure my friends didn't want to get the expansion but guess what, I just play the base game with them because thats what they have. Even if this weren't standalone NOTHING would be any different. So despite what you may read in other reviews, this game is great, the devs worked hard, and Titans" was never a problem.

I strongly recommend this game to anyone who likes rts games because it really brings a lot of new stuff to the genre. It's not the best rts out there but what it tries to do
date: it does well enough to be enjoyable at least casually."

reviewText:
PA is an RTS that has dared to do something different and has succeeded.  For the most part, I've only played the Titans version, and found that it brings a very different style of play vs C&C, Blizzard RTSs and the like.  The campaign is good at getting you accustomed to the game and multiplayer proves fun too.  With bots, vehicles, air, orbital, naval, and artillery as viable strategies, there's a great deal of ability to vary gameplay.  For the most part, balance is also well done such that there isn't one particular strategy that will always win the day.

Downsides
1) It's occasionally buggy, though improved from what it used to be like.  On occasion a mission will start with a white map for me, but a quick restart of the game generally sorts it with no gameplay lost.
2) It can also become a bit monotonous if you let it—it's up to you to be creative in your gameplay to keep yourself interested.  But this can be said of many RTS games.

Overall, I would definitely recommend playing.

Let me, instead, respond to the negative reviews:\n\nPoor UI" (user interface): Coming from a huge fan of the original StarCraft which makes me very fond of the sequel

helpfulPercent: I repeat
votesHelpful:
NO graphics card and I only have issues when I go up against 10 bots. Upgrade your system or don't play against 10 bots or 15 players.

"I payed $90 and didn't get Titans for free": You "pledged" $90 to see this game come to life. Some people pledged and/or outright donated up to $250 and were happy with their decision. This should sum it up - http://steamcommunity.com/app/386070/discussions/0/521643320349717574/
There are plenty like this thread if you Google it. Everyone wants the game for free at this point.

"The AI is dumb": Get a mod! There are so many people who back this game up and help create mods to make it even better! I personally went to them for issues when I first purchased the game and they are super friendly and helpful. And I personally find it hilarious when the AI kills itself (which happens to be rare

and possibly patched now).

"The Devs gave up on it": Not really. They're pretty busy with updates and future projects/games. I feel that Steam users like to throw this phrase around a lot more than it's needed.

All in all

On a serious note:
The devs are appearently horribly people- not my opinion, but a common one. The game is still seriously entertaining, I got my friend a copy when it was on sale we have had some good times with more to come. Also- while the mods are unoffical, they are there. You have to download some third party stuff, and I haven't used them.

Pros:
Multiplayer is fun
Easy to use in-game system creator if the prebuilts ones don't suit your needs.
Surprising amount of content.
Multi-tier bots
PIP and camera anchors for easy management: If you do it right, you can manage an entire solar system easily.
Planet KIllers

Cons:
Beginning is a little bit repitive, so is singleplayer
Terrerian is also repitive
Had a few fps issues and graphical bugs, but they seem rare.

Summary:
Great game, but lots of drama over expectations and everything. Still, doesn't make this a bad game. I rather enjoy it.

reviewText:
This game has some serious potential.



I dont know what everyone is talkingn about with the titans and the DLC and not getting it.. it sounds like the devs made a dumb choice in the beginning but that doesnt effect you if you purchase the game now.

So lets start off with THE GOOD

This RTS is ground breaking.. it has some of the best units and structures i have ever seen in an RTS... if you like Supreme Commander 2... you will like this game.. it seems like they took many of the units and structures right from that game. Everything from Noah Unit Cannons to Experimental Units (Titans in this game) --Sorry.. no Robotic T-REX lol

All commanders have access to the same units regardless of what commander you pick.. there is no Faction" based units that are similar with differences.. such as in starcraft. which i dont mind at all really.

in addition to the traditional LAND and AIR units... you now also have BOT units.. which act like a group all their own.. less durable and less damaging than the rest by far.
date:
.. but easily manufactured fast and in great numbers... there is also the ORBITAL units which orbit the planet or you can send them off to another planet.

You can build teleporters to easily transfer troups from one side of the galaxy to another.. which is nice and its not a very big galaxy.. it might sound more daunting than it really is... for example... a radar plane would probably be able to travel a full revolution around a plant in about 30 seconds or so.. while obviously taking longer for ground units.. maybe a few minutes... traveling from your planet to anotehr can take a minute or two depending if its in your system or an outlieing planet.

The battles can be massive... the troups are amazing.. and the overall gamepplay feels great..


THE BAD

In multiplayer games... the spawn system needs work.. if there are 3 plantes with 5 starting locations or more.. for a total  of 15 spawn points and you have say 8 players... the odds you are going to end up picking the same exact spawn point as an enemy commander is a posibility... and it sucks when that happens.. Hopefully they will turn the spawn system into a draft kind making it so no 2 players can spawn at the same location but maybe highlight whereb your teammates have picked if they are going before you so you can spawn close to them if you want.

There is a serious lack of customization in multiplayer set up for custom games.. all you really have control over if the map (or star system) which you can also customize i think. But you cant say... restrict the game to only LAND units.. if you wanted.. or only air.. and you cant turn off devastating effects like Nukes.... there is also a unit if you build it.. and complete it... it destroys the planet it is on.. which is neat.. but not fun when you are on a planet that gets wiped out.. there is another unit that will essentially thwor a plant at your planet destroying both... which is also not fun.. there needs to be an ability to turn these types of units off..

The ORBITAL units are neat.. but annoying after a while.. the abilitiy to turn off specific units is also missing so you could use only transports and radar vehicles from the orbital structures.. that would be nice.. but sadly.. you cant do that.

The matchmaking is bad right now.. not many players online... most i have seen is 3000... but once it really gets gooing that will hopefully pick up... almost no one does ranked.. ive only managed to do one ranked match withoiut waiting for more than 10 minutes..

there is no campaign... there are galactic battles where you travel from star system to star system on a map unlocking aditional paths when you beat one and then unlocking tech that will benifit you later in the planets from then on.
recommended:
. there really isnt a goal for that. i dont see the point.

the tutorial feels only about half done.. it doesnt touch on most of the units or special units.. it doesnt tell you what to do with gas planets and i had to find ouyt on my own watching other players use them for energy sources from orbital units.. and i was like OHHH..



OVERALL i woulkd recommend this game.. but not for more than 20 dollars.. i got it 70% off and i was happy with the purchase.. wait for a sale or watch a lot of gameplay before you decide to get it.. hopefully since its still early access that it will get better.. but its a good waste of time right now."

reviewText:
On the topic of the game itself,

Still a good game despite what some would say, breaks boundaries for me and in my opinion it is a very good RTS. Fight over one planet, two planets- entire solar systems. Game keeps moving at a constant pace due to the plethora of ways to annihilate campers such as nukes, titans, self destruct mining lasers that drill to the core of the planet, death star esque annihilasers, orbital bombardment capable battleships & satellites, and a large array of units. Never have boundaries aside from the terrain and the edge of the solar system you're fighting in. My one piece of advice to you if you decide to pick up this game; never stop expanding and attacking your enemy or you will soon face total annihilation!

On the topic of the game's re-release,

Ultimately I feel like it was a bad call for the re-release, developers should have worked on the game they had and earned back the respect they lost during the early life of the game. I feel like if they released Titans at a much cheaper price, or perhaps just let it loose as a free DLC it would have driven many more sales and the steam reviews would've started to turn around. The developers had their reasons for doing things how they did, and ultimately I've chosen to forgive them over what I believe is a minor transgression. Don't let the drama stop you from coming in as a new player, chances are we'll only have a better game from here on out.

reviewText: Great game! Impresively deep with its strategy and play style. I like the fact that combat can take place on land, sea, air, and orbital. Makes for some great options. My only complaint (which is shared by many, I'm sure) is that there are no different factions to force play style. That's really all a faction is: a forced change in play-style and artistic theme. While the change in artistic theme isn't an option, the different ways to play was many. You can build nothing but builders and defenses, then nuke the world into submission (like the terran's from StarCraft). You can spam cheap units early on and try to rush them (Zerg). Or you can build a massive air army and slowly glass the planet (Protos). So, while you're not forced into options, you're also not giving away your play-style with your faction. Give and take. Would recommend.
voteText: 9 of 21 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Gone are the days of spamming keys in a rts to get what you want done.
Planetary Annihilation is an rts on a sphere.  Though I understand and share in the frustration with others that the game has had some god awful PR,  it didn't stop me from playing.  With the advent of titans, the game is more or less complete.
I can say for certain that this game has quite a lot of toys to play with and to learn.   Being a top 10 player, I can say that you can play this game competitively.
There are plenty of ease of use features that make the large scale of PA a doable task.  Team games can be played in a shared army" format meaning all members share the same units and resources.  You can queue up countless orders.  Area commands quite potentially could redefine the genre.
If you do buy this game
date: make sure you download Planetary Annihilation Mod Manager from the uberent forums.  There are a few bad game design decisions that can be fixed through UI mods usable in any multiplayer game."

reviewText:
A lot of the other reviews are saying that this game is just the previous game updated and released for full price some time later. I wouldn't know about that since I have not played the other games. In my personal opinion I like this game and I really enjoy the whole planet annihilation aspect of the game, it feels great the first time that you destroy an entire planet. I like that there are five different types of units ( air, orbital, bots, ground vehicles, and naval ) although I feel that naval units aren't that great since you can't transport them to other planets and there isn't usually a ton of water on planets unless you make a custom solar system, which brings me to the next topic. You can make your own solar systems. There are about six different planets that you can choose to make and asteroid belts and moons.

Overall

Graphics: 9/10 I like the art style

Gameplay: 7/10 I would like to see some more things done with naval units and maybe a way to transport air units to other planets

I recommend that you try this game out for yourself and if you don't like it you can get it refunded by steam as long as you have less than two hours on the game and bought it within two weeks time.

DISCLAIMER: You may need to put the graphics to low if there are a lot of units in the game and if there are a lot of planets in the system.

reviewText:
Anyone reading this will have read up on the negative reviews based upon the re-release of the expansion as a full priced game.  I fully agree that this was a bad call from the companies standpoint, someone in the hierarchy wanted to make a quick buck and shame on them for duping the community like this.  Having said that, the game is quite good, I purchased the original for $29.99 CAD and got the expansion for $10.94 CAD.  Overall, I'm pretty happy withis arrangement as the rerelease is quite good and reminiscent of SupCom.

Mechanics wise, you will want a PC that isn't entry level as planet dynamics and no unit caps will slow down with just the sheer number of physics calculations made, however it will run really well on any mid-high pcs.

Gameplay is your typical Total Annihilation mass unit genre with Titans thrown in.  The numerous ways to destroy a planet gives unspoken objects and can get quite hectic as you race to destroy your opponent's commander.

I would recommend this to anybody at a decreased price point (70% off right now), since it is a quality game.... it just had a very shaky start.

reviewText: The original Planetary Annihilation actually had me rather disenchanted.  I bought it very early on, and it had lots of problems, and then I hadn't played it in quite a while.  Over the Christmas break I fired it up again and it was like an entirely different game.  My son and I played it for several hours and then started seriously considering Titans.  Titans itself isn't really a significant evolution beyond the original Planetary Annihilation, but it was really cheap for people who were early buyers so looking at it as an expansion pack it was well priced.  I enjoy playing this, though I do find it a bit too easy to destroy a planet with the Ragnarok.

reviewText:
This game gets a bad rap. It's my go-to RTS. It's not perfect, and I don't expect it to get much better, but I really enjoy it. Developers made some PR missteps, and there are seemingly simple-to-fix things that probably won't ever be addressed. ...But I don't care. It's a fun game. It rarely crashes. Good gameplay.

My top three Cons:
- three halfway decent humans vs a couple of good AIs eventually bogs down the game (SLOOWWWW) if there's no easy endgame
- no quick overlays for things like: radar coverage, anti-air coverage, anti-ground coverage, etc.
- lack of economy sharing controls

,,,and yet I keep playing with my old TA/BA pals.
voteText: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I contributed to PA and now PA has been ANNIHILATED because of this game. You know what? I don't mind that at all. So now we have stuff that really should have been in PA but who cares? Not me...I am happy with this. I will say that if your computer can't run this game at high settings then you're gonna have a really bad time. It will crash frequently (played it on a crappy laptop several times, it ran but often was frustrating) but if you have a decent PC you'll be fine.

If you're griping about the company and the politics behind this game then understand that basically you will never be satisfied with any game ever because you'll look at the company first. I think Uber did make some bad decisions when starting this game and are not very good business men to begin with (see Human Resources"...oh wait...) but they amazingly got this kickstarted. I think Patrick Lowery had some part in that because hearing the original narration for the trailer got me harder than the core of a dying star. But if you focus on the politics you lose sight of the game...speaking of which:

Pros:
-Smashing Planets
hoursPlayed:
or just engulfing a planet in units is far more satisfying than it has any right to be
-Lots of units to play with and the Titans add to that
-Galactic Warfare gives a bit of a story to the fray
-Multiplayer is pretty sleek and works well enought to lose friends properly in

Cons:
-Some balance need to happen for certain situations (see "Dox Rush" or "Spider Bomb Rush")
-Commander Customization doesn't exist
voteText: you get what you get or what you want to pay for\n-While Galactic Warfare gives a bit of story the game really doesn't have one except what was piggybacked off of TA and Supreme Commander. Humans are gone
helpfulPercent: robots are ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Moving on.\n\nOverall I praise the hell out of this game because it brings me back to when I was a kid and playing TA with so much going on. Nukes

votesFunny: the map in chaos...lots of fun times to be had. Now add all that with officially obliterting a planet and you have a damn good game to play. Give the Devs as much flak as you want and complain that you were a kickstarter and blah blah blah but at the end of the day if you're pulling things from the company that made it more than the game then the game must not be that bad."

reviewText:
Very good RTS, with well paced gameplay and endless possible strategies. That being said, there are a few problems

The autopathing is TERRIBLE. Units will get stuck in a corner, clump together, and take weird routes when you give them a destination

The optimization is very bad. This game probably crashes more than any other game I own, and it eats an absurd amount of ram.

The maps are hit or miss. Sometimes they will be well balanced, other times one player will have a huge starting advantage over the others

Still a very fun game, and the titans expansion is definitely worth purchasing

reviewText: I'm not a big RTS player, but this really grabbed me. The graphics, beautiful. Everything had the massive sense of scale that a game played on a galactic scale needs, and yet still had enough detail in each of the units for me to just spend five or so minutes staring at my units, admiring how nice they look. The sound design was fantastic, even though I got one or two glitches, sound effects playing at the wrong time, etc, it wasn't anything really noticeable until I tried pushing the game to its limits, which brings me to my next point: performance. The game ran AMAZINGLY, supporting hundreds of units on screen at any given time, even when I had a second picture in picture screen displaying some of the busiest regions of the game. I almost never experienced lag, and when I did, it was generally because of a background task on my computer. As for the gameplay, as I said I'm not a big RTS player so I can't really compare it to much, but what I have played is thoroughly entertaining - addictive even. Since I spent about 4 hours straight playing matches of the game over and over, I reckon you could say I liked it. All in all, definitely worth the $31 US it costs, but if you're not willing to spend that much, wait for it to go on sale, and buy it. Either way, buy this game, because it's all round fantastic.

reviewText:
So, I've been asked many times to write a review for Planetary Annihilation.
Be sure to check out my overview on youtube
Should you have any feedback, comments, questions or suggestions, post them below and I'll try to answer them to the best of my ability!

Before I begin, I'd just like to ask a favor of the reader - that you think critically and look into the merits and flaws of each review, including this one. I've seen damning reviews by people who have barely spent any time with PA, or by those new to strategy games, or who disregard the game because of spherical maps. Are those really worth your consideration?
I'll outline my biases here and now: I did not kickstart the game, I purchased the Alpha prior to launch and have played and made youtube content for PA ever since (for about 2+ years as of the time of this review). I have a good rapport with the developers and have attended PA's PAX booth by invitation. Obviously I am invested in the game, the community and the development team. That said, I am going to make this review as open-minded as possible.

What is PA?It's a massive scale RTS game where you can command 1000s of units across a whole solar system with a variety of strategies open to you. A robust planet(map) generation system allows essentially unlimited map variation at your fingertips. Indeed there are a number of planet 'biomes' creating different strategic options themselves from desert and ice and oceanic biomes to earth, moon and lava and even the resource rich gas giants! Of course, as a new player you will need to allow some time to get used to the idea of spherical maps in an RTS game and how to navigate and orientate yourself. There are features to help with this; togglable Pole-Lock ensures that the planet's orientation remains constant. Gone are the days of turtling into a corner; you now have a corner of 360 degrees of approach.
In game, there are many modalities of combat; land (vehicles and bots), sea, air and even an orbital layer. Fancy building a base on that moon over there - go and do it, launch an attack from it at a beachhead you have established on a different planet - do it. It's all up to what you decide to do in any given game. There are many different mechanics in the game as well like Unit cannons, periodically available asteroids and planet destruction methods. Such include planetary engines, super-lasers and now the Ragnarok Titan. Of course there is the nuclear option, should you decide to invest the resources.
The game is also easily moddable with a thriving mod scene established since alpha. Visit the Uber forums to download PAMM (PA Mod Manager) to have instant access to UI and server mods created by the community as well as map packs from a variety of creators.

What does the TITANS standalone expansion bring to the party?The unit pool has been expanded greatly with TITANS and is definitely worth the upgrade for existing PA owners and easily worth the purchase price for prospectives.  TITANS also brings improvements to terrain with a much better scaled than 'classic' PA, as well as a new 'Bounty mode' where you get economic bonuses depending on how many people you knocked out. The expansion also brings polish to the game, along with AI and Galactic War improvements. Let's not forget the host of new units, 21 to be precise as well as 5 badass titans refers you back to my overview video above. This expansion also sees the return of unit wreckage, which players can reclaim for resources, as well as 'hover' units enabling new strategies to circumvent water and lava obstacles.

I've played PA and it was pretty meh
date: why should I reconsider?"I will admit that PA
recommended: prior to TITANS was at a stage where
hoursPlayed: I believe
voteText: it was beginning to stagnate. Since release a number of big features were added that spurred discussion

votesHelpful: Unit Cannons
votesTotal: Asteroids and full planet smashing) though aside from that PAs updates consisted mainly of general polish
votesFunny: bug-fixing
commentsCount: AI and pathing improvements etc. While this is not to say that these improvements haven't had a cumulative impact over time

reviewText:
You have most likely seen so many negative reviews.... Its all f******g b******t , For one, The original game was stunning, glitchy and crashy maybe, but still one of the best games i have ever bought. As for Titans, If you owned the original, it is rather pricy considering it isnt a full remake. But even so, This game brings fun and strategy together like you have never seen before. It gives you limitless options;Orbital strikes,Orbital defense, Orbital Army, Orbital domination, Naval Strikes, naval defenses, NAval army, Naval dominatiopn, Suicide bots, Not cannons, Bot/vehicle army, Tank Artillery strikes, OVerall domination, Artillery strikes, Artillery defense, Air defense, air bombers, Pelicans, Zeus lightning ships, Atlas sei(awesome)mic titan, Ares moving fortress, Orbital teleporter, Nano bot swarms, death star laser blast, Colliding planets , Nuking planets core's.

If this game is on sale, you should have already bought it, if its not, you should be saving up. THis game runs smoothly unless you get ridiculous. 10v10 Mini moon matches, 1v1v1v1v1v1 Pax ffa's, Ai skirmishes, Galatic wars, Mods, Player vs com. Challenging ai and AWESOME SOUNDTRACK(like seriously the best soundtrack i've ever heard) are all just normal features of this amazing game.

TLDR: THis game is friggin awesome if you like blowing planet sup and destroying EVERYTHING! Buy it now!

reviewText:
Very well made game, If you're looking for another supcom FA you will be dissapointed, but it lends enough concepts that the game will feel familiar. Spherical maps and planet hopping is a nice change from the usual rectangular maps.

Alot of people are hating on the game, because Uber made some bad decisions in the beginning and partly because of a sense of entitlement. reviewText:
Keep in mind this game is an expandalone. You do not need to own Planetary Annhilation to purchase this.
$40 for people that do not own the base game.
$13.59 for people that do own the base game on steam.


Very solid, fast paced, and intense real time strategy game. This RTS is demanding in brain and computer power, both needing more power as the game gets bigger.

Strategy:
Requires knowledge of the game to combat a moderately skilled player. Terrain affects troop movements, unit composition, and overall strategy.

System Editor:
Create a system of your liking and play in it with your friends or randoms. These will not be used in 1v1 competitive, only official maps will be used for those. Add asteroids, metal planets, ocean planets, even create a custom planet!

1v1 Competitive:
Challenging and intense matches take place in the 1v1 competitive scene. You probably will lose your first games due to the experienced players in ladder. To get better, watch replays of advanced players. See how they play, I watched a few and started winning instantly. Many buildings/units are not used in 1v1 because many of them are for very long games with huge systems.

Custom:
This is where the interplanetary battling takes place. Create huge systems and go to battle against your enemies systems away. Most of the units not used in 1v1 are used here. Most fun with huge battles with friends.

There are many units and strategies to use and infinite possibilities. Smash planets into your foes, teleport nukes into your enemy's base, there are many game finishers to choose from.

TL;DR: Planetary Annhilation Titans is a fun, fast paced RTS that challenges new players and provides intense battles that span the solar system. Worth it, especially with friends.

reviewText:
This is an amazing real time strategy game with excellent multiplayer support. With so many different types of mobile units and structures.. there are many many strategies you can try to implement. It's a lot like rock paper scissors, but with dynamite, spaceships and Titans.. and oh yeah, it's actually fun.

There isn't a whole lot of story to the campaign. It's just you systematically taking over the galaxy and not really that interesting, but its a good place to learn how to play. I'm more into the multiplayer.. there are always custom games to join, and the ranked matchmaking never seems to take long to find you a match.

I did play Total Annihilation years ago, which is why i bought this game when I stumbled upon it. I'm not disappointed.

reviewText: If you like RTS and strategy games in general and you are willing to learn, you might want to consider getting this. Has a good amount and variety of units (all are more or less useful, no clear losers"). Has a deep-ish learning curve. Maps are spheres! Has a flowing economy
date: meaning that the resources will never run out on the maps. Also the community has made some great maps if the ones in the game are getting a bit dull. Has singleplayer (a campaign wannabe and skirmish) and multiplayer.\n\nSo you might be wondering what changed in PA:Titans that is not in vanilla PA. For a slight increase in price compared to PA (which is not even sold anymore) you get the titan units
recommended: some normal units and a more balanced game. Also if you have PA:T but your friend(s) only have PA you can still play with them!\n\nI have to admit though that the game has some more or less annoying bugs. Pathing issues (becomes more and more common the more units there are on the map)
hoursPlayed: joining lobbies and ranked games
voteText:
joining games that you got disconnected from and a few others that i cant remember from the top of my head. But most of the bugs aren't really that common and there are easy workarounds.

The game runs pretty well on my not so good laptop (depends on what you consider "well"). But as always you should check the minimum requirements before you buy anything. The game is not graphics intensive but it takes  quite a bit of CPU (loading the systems for example). I haven't really experienced that many connection problems and it's more than likely that it's your own internets fault than the games fault. If you experience problems with the game you should go and find the games forums and ask for support/solutions there.

PS. I believe that the reason why uber didn't make PA:T a DLC is because the reviews of PA were full of outdated complaints and some unnecessary hate.

PPS. I know there are people who are actively hating the game and Uber. But please
helpfulPercent: do not hate a good game (if you think it's good) just because the company that made it is not so great. Have fun Annihilating!"

reviewText:
I gave PA: Vanilla a not recommend.  It had a host of technical and gameplay issues that warranted it.

PA: titans on the other hand is a whole different story.  Uber double downed on the quality for this expansion and it shows.  Well worth the price asked, and probably the only modern RTS now adays worth playing aside from SC2.  I've always been a gameplay person, and while PA certainly doesn't slouch when it comes to graphics, player interaction is where this game really shines.  Earns my strong recommendation

Goods:
- Plenty of new unique units and map terrain that add alot of new gameplay depth and unit interaction.
- Complete balance pass which sees the tier 2 roster finally viable (~50% of all units)
- Great ui polish and revamped sound/visual effects
- Interactive tutorial
- New bounty mode in FFA which better rewards players who take risks.
- Sweet mega units
- friendly community

Bad:
- Teething problems with some bugs and other misc issues, but none that are common enough to really affect the average player.

reviewText:
TITANS adds a lot of flavour to Planetary Annihilation. In particular, it makes combat in the Orbital layer feel much more vibrant and the expanded unit roster opens up new strategies and makes army composition matter that much more.

The expansion's namesake units, the Titans, are fantastically designed. When I play with friends on Teamspeak, there are shouts and screams whenever one of them hits the battlefield, either of panic or of triumph. I'm a particularly big fan of the situations the Ragnarok planet-destroying building cause, because those turn into a frantic last stand as one team struggles for survival.

You will have hours of fun with this game, and Uber Entertainment are a fantastic team that continue to punch well above their weight in the RTS market. I'm sure they have plenty more in store for TITANS later on.

reviewText:
This game's pretty good. I didn't play the origional, I found this game a few days before it was release and then followed it and then eventually bought it.

PROS:
-I can play the game on the highest settings even if there is a lot of movement on screen.
-I have never ever have the game crash.
-Overall very creative.
-All factory-type robots are balanced. Example:
*Bots are quicker to make and are excellent infantry.
*Vehicles do more damage and are harder to kill, but are slower to move and build.
*Air has the best mobility, but probably the easiest to kill (in my experience).
*Orbital has the least amout of choices for robots, but can only be targeted by certain defences and bots.
*And Naval (My favorite), Extreme range, damage, health, targeting abilities (some of them can defeat orbital), and submarines, which also can only be targeted by certain defences and bots. Downside is that you need to have water, which can sometimes be abundant. I prefer to start of on planets with water because the naval units (along with an upgraded radar and a few Holkins) can defend you well.

CONS
-So far only bug fixes, no major updates.
-Starting off is hard due to the lack of resources.
-There is no tutorial, which kinda sucks.
-The game is basically over the moment someone gets all 5 catalysts in a machine planet, although some guy I played with kept on nuking a catalyst the moment I was almost done with the last one about 3 times, but unfortunately, I was still able to finish it and destroy the rest of the planets.

Overall, it's great, but get it on sale. Not worth 40 bucks unless they add some new content, because some of the players who had the original said that there was barely anything new added.

I rate this game 8/10
If it had factions, I really think it could be a 10/10 game.

reviewText:
Intuitive controls so even someone not very good at RTS like me can play it easily. Tutorial was enough to get me started and covered most of what I needed to know. Galactic War is keeping me engaged so far. I think it will for a while as there are many different ways to play the game, especially with tech.

Runs completely fine on my PC. Hasn't crashed once. That being said I have a 2500K cpu and a GTX 980 TI gpu so that might be the reason. Also running it on W7 so maybe that is more stable.

My biggest complaint is that there doesn't seem to be procedurally generated maps in galactic war. So you end up playing the same planets over and over again. I honestly would have preferred the variety of generated maps over the balance/asthetics of premade maps.

I didn't have the original release and I paid 30$ for the Titan version. I think it was well worth the money.

reviewText:
I've kind of been ashamed of my generation of gamers after reading some of these comments and reviews.
People who own PA are upset that they didn't get it for free, so instead of waiting for it to go on sale at a future date (because apparently a little over 10 dollars is assenine to ask for a year's worth of work), they find any negative review at all and upvote it.

I ask most humbly, have you considered that a seperate release breathes new life back into the game? That it attracts new players, builds a stronger foundation for the community, and shows that Uber really wants to get back into the good graces of their players? They gave a free copy to their 40,000+ kickstarter backers and offer it to everyone who owned the game and bought it at any other point for a very generous price. How entitled have we gotten as gamers? Have we forgotton that it takes money to MAKE games, that we wouldn't have products like this and amazing revivals as this one has been if there weren't HUMAN BEINGS  pouring their souls into it?

Wait until it goes on sale in a year if you must. Buy it at 5 dollars like you did PA. Don't make it your personal mission to be upset that you weren't given it for free. Or, you know what? Spend the 13 dollars. Most games would charge a LOT more for a DLC" of this magnitude. It really is something new entirely. It isn't what you think you were promised with the Kickstarter. reviewText:
Planetary Annihilation: TITANS is an expandalone to Uber Entertainment's previous title, the Kickstarter funded Planetary Annihilation.

The GameAssuming you haven't played the original PA before, let me lay down what this games are about. Planetary Annihilation is about managing an economy and building up a giant base with which you build an even giant-ER army. Where some games have your battles span miles, this game has your battles span multiple planets. Vehicles come in a number of variations, from 4 archetypes; you have access to ground vehicles, robot units, aircraft and ships. In addition to those there are also the orbital units, which have often highly specialized roles.

With these tools you go about conquering worlds, destroying your enemies (lamentations of their women optional) and, if you are so inclined, BLOWING UP THE VERY PLANETS THEY CALL HOME.

That's right, you can blow up planets in this game. With other planets even. Want to be spiteful and throw one of your enemy's planets into one that belongs to their allies'? This game allows you to do that.

The ExpansionNow you might be thinking that this all sounds pretty sweet, and you'd be right in thinking that. But what of this expansion? What does it do?

It turns everything up to 11.

Not only does this expansion add a host of regular new units, including but not limited to a nanobot swarm and a younger brother to your already impressive commander unit, it also adds the titular TITANS. TITANS are basically super-units. Have you ever wanted to destroy your enemies by stepping on them with a giant robot? Now you can. Did all that talk about interplanetary units made you wish you could have giant space-battleships? This expansion has it. Giant teleportation deathstar satellite? Yes'm, all here.

It also comes with a bunch of smaller enhancements to the game that I won't bore you with here, look up the patch notes on those if you're so inclined.

The ConclusionThis all brings us to the question of the hour: is this game worth buying?

Now you must understand that I was already quite fond of the original, having played it 69 hours (Ha! That's never changing now) so I came into this with that as the base to my experience. But it still surpassed my expectations and has wowed me with all the cool new stuff you can do now.

The best thing about this one though is that it added that one key thing that I always thought the original lacked.

Character

If you've never played Planetary Annihilation, this game is unlike anything you've played before. If you have, you owe it to yourself to give this one a shot. It's got everything good about the original with everything that even I didn't know I missed about it. This is the way to do an expansion. It's the Yuri's Revenge to Planetary Annihilation's Red Alert 2.

It's worth your money, and may even prove itself worthy of your admiration.

reviewText:
Allrighty. So youre looking at this game and thinking if you should buy it.

Scroll to bottom for pros and cons if youre not up for the massive reading

First off ill go ahead and mention that TITANS is an expantion on the original game: Planetary Annihilation, this expansion adds 5 Titan class units and a dozen or so other smaller units, the original game is probably one of the best RTS games currently for its price. If you dont know it allready, theres quite a few of bugs and smaller glitches currently on TITANS but they are working on fixing them with roughly monthly updates

Before i begin you should know the Titans

There are 5 Titans currently in the game (dont know if more are coming)

They consist of 3 land units, 1 orbital, and 1 air

The Titans are:         Ragnarok (after finishing the build it will make the planet it is built on go boom within a minute)

Ares (basically a moving fortress, near impossible to kill without air, has extreme range and can move across ocean)

Atlas (The most commonly seen Titan, it can move through ocean and land and causes minor nukes whenever something stands in its way, not as tanky as the Ares but has more damage and is very vulnerable to kiting and air)

Zeus (the second most commonly seen Titan is probably this one, its an air unit, meaning it can fly over any terrain and cant be hit by regular tanks and such, it has a massive damage AOE attack with relatively short range, very vulnerable to airfighters or orbital)

Now that you know the titans you should also know that they all have weaknesses, allthough most of the time one is built its gameover for the other player(s) unless they have one or more to counter it. This means that much of mid-lategame is just rushing a Titan. Other than that the Multiplayer is very stable for the most part and i have not experienced many issues other than a few bugs here and there. The original game is extremely well balanced, i havent yet settled for wether or not TITANS is balanced

Now then, the singleplayer, or Galactic War as the game calls it is VERY fun compared to alot of other RTS games singleplayer modes. The AI is very well programmed for newbies, but can also be ramped up by alot to fit better players.
Anyway, the general theme of Galactic war is that you have very limited options that expand as you conquer and annihilate, for example you will start with vehicle factories only, but when you conquer a solarsystem you get 3 random techs to choose one of, that tech will then unlock something for you, for example; Advanced Vehicle factories, and then you basically keep going, fighting bots untill you find their HQ and destroy him.

The learning curve isnt too steep, you can just learn the basics in Galactic War before you run into Multiplayer, that way you wont have teammates going full CAPSLOCK-heavybreathing-rage

And as promised in the top of the review i will go ahead and give my ratings and Pro´s and Con´s

General ratings

AI         9/10
-Multiplayer         8-9/10
-Singleplayer         9/10
-General balance         9.5/10 (bomber spam can be very OP)
-TITANS balance         8/10
-Micromanagement         8/10
-Visuals         10/10 (LOVE the graphics)
-Sounds         7/10
-Amount of bugs         2/10 (very few)
-Pathfinding         7/10 (Titans can be a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥)
-Community         9/10 (almost allways willing to give advice or other sorts of help)
-Planetary Annihilation         10/10 (YOU CAN EXPLODE PLANETS OMG!)


Pros

-Graphics: LOVE THEM SO MUCH

-Gameplay: Pretty god damn solid and replayable, does get repetetive after 3-4 games for me atleast

-Community: For the most part very friendly, unless youre playing shared army and touch their fabbers or units.

-Planetary Annihilation: SEROSLY YOU CAN BLOW UP ENTIRE PLANETS ITS AWESOME!!!

Cons

-Does get a bit repetetive after a certain amount of games/time, but easy to spring back into after a while

-Titans can be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ when trying to micromanage them

-Bombers in massive amounts are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ OP if you dont have Tier 2 anti-air

-Long loadtime if you dont have an SSD or a great computer

-Can get very laggy if games get dragged out

And yes i know i didnt explain the basics and all, but if you want them they will be down here

Commander dies = you lose

Factories build units

Air builds at mediocre speeds is fast and can travel anywhere but squishy,

Vehicles take a bit longer to build and are slow but strong,

Bots are easy to massproduce and rely on speed and numbers

If you see an Atlas heading for you and you lack an army of bombers, youre ♥♥♥♥ed

reviewText: The ultimate RTS just got better. TITANS is a must-have addition to Planetary Annihilation that adds 21 all-new units and 5 brand new TITANS to tower over your foes. The new Planetary Annihilation update goes hand-and-hand with this standalone expansion, adding an element of terrain to the battlefield along with countless improvement, balances, and bug-fixes. All in all, a must-have for Planetary Annihilation veterans and a steal for newcomers to the game. Planetary Annihilation: TITANS does not require Planetary Annihilation, but TITANS does come with regular Planetary Annihilation in addition and you can switch between the two games in the Settings>Gameplay menu.

reviewText:
Okay you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s sold me on it. And I bought it. And you know what? I don't regret it.

Yea I'm still a little ticked off that I had to pay extra for this, even though I feel like a lot of this should have been in the original game to begin with, but after the complete cluster @#$% that was the original, broken, unoptimized, glitchy, buggy, even long after it got released, you guys really seem to have gotten your act together with this new game.

I'm still salty that it wasn't free for returning players, but someone made a good point: Having looked at your sales on steamspy, and comparing it to similar games, I can't believe you even bothered to keep patching the original when you already had everyone's money. Really puts into perspective whether or not you actually care about us. To give away Titans for free would not have been financially practical. I'm a developer too and I understand you don't do this for leisure. So I'll allow it.

But for new players? $40? It's a bargain.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This part is for old players coming to Titans. Skip this part if you never played the original.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

New units.

Big whoop, right? Well the units actually add a depth and complexity that was horribly lacking in the original. I was skeptical, but after my first online game where my base got SWARMED BY PROBABLY A THOUSAND BOMB-BOTS THROUGH A TELEPORTER, I think it's safe to say that one unit added a lot--and it's not the only new unit. Despite numbering in the thousands, these little buggers didn't feel overpowered. We already countered a wave of them once in this game, and this second wave nearly succeeded only because it was exploiting a major weakness on the planet I was on. I had no ground defenses or even aerial backup! Thirty more seconds and I was screwed. Luckily my team mate had finished the catalyst in the nick of time and just as my planet was being swarmed, my commander and air fabrication units franticly making defenses as a last ditch effort, we BLEW THEIR PLANET TO BITS and won. Was a great game.

The terrain.

No one is even talking about this but I feel like this is horribly overlooked. A few simple changes in terrain elevation makes the map SO MUCH MORE INTERESTING than the boring spheres in the original. Now you can fortify the high ground and build bases in valleys. All in all it's a lot more interesting.

THE GAME ACTUALLY RUNS NOW WITHOUT A SUPERCOMPUTER.

Now I upgraded to a pretty beefy PC, but the original game was still chugging harder than a frat boy crashing an afterparty at the biggest college in the state. The game ran like absolute crap. Now it doesn't! Even with a REDICULOUS number of units in a 3v3 match, the game held up pretty consistently up until the end, when we got hit by the ungodly swarm of bomb bots skittering through a teleporter.



Just for reference, here's my specs. And I was running in windowed mode, too!

Operating System: Windows 7 Home Premium 64-bit (6.1, Build 7601) Service Pack 1 (7601.win7sp1_gdr.150202-1526)
System Manufacturer: Gigabyte Technology Co., Ltd.
Processor: Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790K CPU @ 4.00GHz (8 CPUs), ~4.0GHz
Memory: 16384MB RAM
Available OS Memory: 16268MB RAM
Page File: 3577MB used, 28957MB available
DirectX Version: DirectX 11

Now keep in mind, I very much surpass the required specs. Thing is, the *original* game ran like crap on these specs, because it was horribly coded. Now it's less horribly coded. So the game runs. Previously, everyone complained about the game being slow. Oh well your specs suck." Uh no they don't. Well the game runs now so that statement might be true if the game runs poorly for you. I'm not sure. I just know it works fine for me. Maybe Uber needs to up the required specs / recommended specs.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Here's the part for new players!
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText:
I would recommend this game to anyone who purchased Planetary Annihilation to get the game for cheap.  I wouldn't recommend someone to get the game without it.  Why?

The AI is not very good.  The game takes a best of a machine to run well.  The single player is very bare and not very fun and not only because of the lack of AI.  I would see the AI turtle all their forces and never move, I would see them consistently try to build a teleporter on a planet in the same area every time with only one construction bot, even though it was covered by turrets.

The planets have had terrain heights added but it doesn't seem fully implemented.  Naval gameplay can be completely ignored as there are not many water planets.

The multiplayer is fun, but it is hard to find a game and get into a game.  Disconnects are common.

All this and I'd still recommend.  It is great fun to break onto an enemy held planet and establish a foothold.  The battles look pretty, especially if you add mods to make the battles look even better.  They even have a mod manager available that makes mods as easy to install/uninstall and update as it is with the Steam Workshop.  You can get a lot of time out of this game.

reviewText:
Lot of negativity going around in reviews and the forums that don't concern how good or bad the game is. Just a lot of venting it seems. So here are some facts about the price tag for all interested.

* 40$ Will buy you Titans, which will run on its own without the original game, plus with the new DLC
* It is 13$ or so if you already own PA, which given all the new units, maps and such is fair for new DLC these days.
* They no longer sell PA. No real point the game with its DLC is the same price as PA was a few days ago, maybe even cheaper.

Honestly I do not see where any of it equals a money grab but that is entirely up to each consumer to decide. As it is PA : Titans is a great entry level to play the game.

Now on to the actual game. Is Planetary Annihilation: TITANS any good? That isn't a very easy question to answer as even for fans of Supreme Commander and Total Annihilation, such as myself, there are some very discernable differences in the gameplay as well as many similarities. It will all come down to if the nuances of this game strike your fancy or not. So lets discuss some of the big things fans of those games I mentioned will probably need to know about over all. This is for new PA players as well as those looking at the DLC items.

* Galactic War - This feature pretty much forms the bulk of your singleplayer experience. In it you start with a couple systems and try to take over other systems battle by battle. You start off typically with a barebones of technology. That being the ability to make a basic unit fabricator such as vehicles as well as a few defenses and resource items. After each battle if victorious you can search the planet and chose a technology to boost you for future operations. You only have a limited number of slots so you have to chose wisely. Luckily you can forget some techs or unlock extra tech slots. You continue attacking system to system till you find each of the three enemy factions leader systems and defeat them.

* Planets - The big deal of the game, IE Planetary" Annihilation
date: are the planets. That being sphereical spatial bodies circulating a sun or other planets. These planets form the maps for which you will wage war. Your view of the battlefield might be a bit jarring given its very stark difference from the mostly top down views of the genre. You'll rotate around these planets regularly and depending on your settings
recommended: north might appear south or East might seem north. There are setting in which the game will lock the planets so that north is always north and so on. You can zoom in and out as needed. In the end this feature will probably be the biggest game maker or breaker for most fans.\n\n* Unit Roster - While fundamentally similar to TA or SupComm

votesFunny: much like SupComm form tiers. You start off with tier one and work up to tier two. Unlike SupComm you only have two tiers. Though from my experience there seems to be less filler units and most of them have a very defined purpose. Planetary Annihilation's Units and particularly its buildings function a lot more for the planetary scale. You'll find lots of units meant for planet to planet travel

For instance the Bot Fabricators now offer Sub Commanders in the advanced version. They function similar to SupComm's SubComms in that they are functionally similar to the main commander

What I will say is they all fit well into the theme and have their uses.\n\nThose are the major items of interest in how this game differs from PA Vanilla with its DLC but similar past games such as the popular Supreme Commander. If you are a fan of SupComm or Total Annihilation chances are one of the first two items will decide your enjoyment of the game. As for PA players

extra regular units as well as new maps and other features. From my personal experience I did feel like they filled in some gaps that I felt the game was missing. I only see them as a worthy edition and I didn't mind the 13$ pricepoint at all.

Hope this Review helps. Overall I liked the content even if there is work needed. I'd recommend trying it."

reviewText:
I've played PA for almost 3k hours on and off steam, and I'd all but given up on it.  There were few updates, the balance was static and simplistic, and the orbital layer (including the super weapons) felt like a gimmick.  I told the devs I wouldn't be coming back unless they fixed those problems.

Well, I'm back.  They haven't fixed everything - but they did a damn good job trying.  Orbital now has a basic layer of depth to it - three units in different roles instead of one swarm unit.  Super weapons now have additional members:  the Titans.  For those of you from SupCom, these are experimentals, through and through.  Naval and land now interact in amazing and interesting ways with the addition of hover destroyers, hover tanks, and a nanite swarm that eats everything.  They've finally added a unit that counters the Ultimate Weapon (boom bots):  the lightning bot.

Uber did it right this time.  This should have been the release, absolutely.  But you cannot get salty at Uber - they released early due to financial issues and a previous contract.  This expansion will be to PA what SupCom: FA is to SupCom.

I usually withold my judgement on such things, but this expansion has been in the works for months and months.

I'd also like to take a moment to talk about the price.  For those of you who do not know, the Titans expansion is free for KS backers (due to the risk they took backing Uber), 66% off for previous owners (Veteran players), and $40 for everyone else.  This is, in my book, a sound business decision and a great one for the community.  It's a massive content patch, and it is worth every penny.

Compare that to Elite Dangerous or Guild Wars 2 recent expansion announcements.  They're making their players pay almost full price for those expansions.  You can't tell me Uber is making a money grab when you've got devs like Frontier and ArenaNet running around.

it's EPIC.

But all of this comes with the bitter after taste and the constant reminder that this is what I paid for and was expecting to have about a year ago. I funded this project when it entered BETA (wasn't able to pay for kickstarter) and people are rightfully annoyed by this business maneuver to "re-sell" the old idea for a higher price.


Final word:
The game itself is awesome and I cannot give it a thumbs down without being unfair. Play it

It seems the most reviews aren't about the game.
I quite enjoy Planetary Annihilation: TITANS. and i would recommend it to everyone who likes the RTS genre.

Performance:
I got a 3 year old powerhouse laptop.
and the game runs fine. There are some slowdowns one in a while. like when i got 600 solar planes orbiting a planet.
i dont mind it. because i got 600 solar planes orbiting my planet.

There are a decent number of settings to choose from in the menu. which is important in pc games.

Gameplay:
There are titan units. But i like the other new units more.
There is a hoverboat, drone aircraft carrier. a huge space ship that can attack the ground as well as orbit. and some others. like a proxy commander. its a second commander. (you still lose if you lose your first one).
I enjoy building huge armies. as the doesn't seem to be a build limit.
the feature i like the most is the share army option. the game isnt over when you lose 1 commander. only when you lose all your teams commanders. this way. you and your friends can keep playing together. and you can better manage your army because you got 3 times the attention.

reviewText:
Really enjoy this game! Especially fun with friends.

Speil about titans apparent controversy:
As most people I assume, I was shocked when Titans was released. In the end after I bought it, I feel it was worth the money. Even if / though it could have been handled differently by Uber AND by the community, my attitude is this: if you like the game, support the developers. Pretty simple.

If the only reason you 'don't like the game' is because you have to pay more for it, then you should seriously stop brutalising the devs for it, keep your public whiney mouth shut and just don't buy the damn game.
At the end of the day they aren't stealing your money, they are developing a game!

You feel cheated? That doesn't make the game bad.
You feel like you deserve the game for free? That doesn't make the game bad.
You feel like Uber could have handled their money needs better? That doesn't make the game bad.
You feel like the best use of your time is to call for a boycott? Get a life --> Don't buy the game and move on.
