reviewText:
When I first saw that Titans had been released I was skeptical. I kickstarted the original PA and got burned hard. It had very few units, a number of bugs, was overpriced and many other problems. You can read the other reviews for an idea of the problems.

However, I have been pleasantly suprised by PA:Titans. It has many more units than the original (including Titan units which are extremely cool), nearly all the bugs have been fixed (in my experience anyway, I'm aware this isnt the case for all players) and it has a great competative scene.

I really hope that people give this new revamped PA:Titans a good shot and try to not let the original PA's problems plague them so much. This really is a great game with a lot of potential for even more epicness in the future.

reviewText:
I don't see what all the hate is about here. I do agree it is a bit silly that people who had the original have to now buy this to keep up but I wouldn't call it fair to judge the actual game based off that. As for all the complaints about the AI being too dificult I think this is just new player's frusturated with a very steep learning curve. The AI is actually very bad and does a lot of silly things, very easy to defeat with some experience. I also experienced frustration when first playing over a year ago in the difficulty of beating the AI on the lowest setting. It takes a lot to adjust to this game from more traditional RTS games. As for the game being buggy I have experienced some frustration with the game lagging and crashing. However the issues have been vastly improved since I began playing and appear to continue to improve. I run this game one a machine I built in 2009 with very few issues so I am a little surprised about so many people claiming that the game constantly crashes on their brand new $2500 PC. Most new players also don't realize that most of the game processing actually occurs on Uber's servers and not on the client's side. Doing certain things in game such as setting too many land units on too large of a patrol can cause too many pathing calculations for the game to deal with, avoiding certain (all very unnecessary) actions can prevent the game from lagging and freezing. Though I'll be the first to admit the game isn't perfect and does have a few programming issues there are a lot of great things that make this game stand out and in my opinion very much worth playing. Below I'll list some pros and cons;
Pros
- Three dimensional map allows for completely new strategy forcing players to change their strategies and defend from all sides.
- Single faction allows for highly competitive gameplay where both players always start on an equal field with no faction based advantage to impede upon the competitiveness of the game.
- No unit cap, build as much crap as you like, huge battles.
- Large unit variety allowing for virtually limitless combinations of strategies.
- Need for large build areas and lots of resources impedes players ability to 'turtle' and forces constantly agressive gameplay.
- Kill the commander objective forces players to re-think strategy from previous RTS experiences, keeping players constantly on their toes as a commander snipe can always be just beyond the fog of war.
- Orbital layer of gameplay adds again another level to strategy forcing players to defend their bases even from the space above them. Additionally with multi planet maps players can find numerous ways from massive teleporter invasions and nukes to planet smashes with asteroids and even using the annihilaser to lay siege upon their foes.
- Land, sea, air, and space layers of combat.
- 1v1 ranked matches allows players to quickly connect with another player of a similar skill level for a match on a mirrored planet allowing players to rise up the ranks on an always level playing field.
- Teleporters allow for moving massive number of units across map instantaneously adding yet another level of depth to strategy.
- Live economy forces players to be mindful of how much they are building and how much resources they have available or risk losing radar coverage and experiencing a proportional reduction of production capabilities.
- Mobbing through enemy bases with tons of units destroying everything around is tons of fun.
- Developers constantly improving/refining game, very actively.
- Can switch game mode to vanilla in settings allowing you to still play with friends who do not have the expansion online without having 2 copies of the game installed. Vanilla may also be a good place for new players to learn due to there being less units to manage and learn.
Cons
- Game sometimes buggy; pathing issues at times with complex terrain and large numbers of units, build units refusing to build in places they should be able (sometimes this is from previously queued structures), and very rarely the game freezing out player commands or disconnecting the player altogether but this happens to me very seldom, less than once in ten matches.
- VERY STEEP LEARNING CURVE; this game is not easy to pick up, the variety and scale, along with the live economy, make managing everying very difficult for new players. I would recommend new players watch a few replays on the leaderboards to see what the best players do to win.
- No 'Easy' AI setting. AI on lowest setting very difficult for new players to beat due to previously mentioned learning curve. My recommendation to new players on this is to lower the resource rate for the AI to .5 or lower then slowly turn it up .1 at a time every time until you are able to beat the AI, then when you are comfortable playing at 1.0 rate then turn the AI up to hard. When you can confidently defeat the AI on 'hard' difficulty you are ready for multiplayer.
- Singleplayer mode 'Galactic War' sucks. Don't bother playing it. This is a multiplayer game, the only reason to play singleplayer is for practice and for that I recommend skirmish battles against the AI.
- Internet connection required for gameplay due to way game runs. However as I previously stated this game is only actually fun on multiplayer so this shouldn't really matter.
- Lack of community support and game information due to small player base. The most complete wiki of the game, pamatches.com is no longer kept up and all information is now very obsolete forcing players to look in game for information on unit meta. Hopefully this will change soon with the introduction of a new player base from the Titan Wars expansion.
- Had to pay $13 for the expansion. However I purchased the original during a steam summer sale for only $23 so I wasn't too upset.
In all I find it kind of disappointing that so many people have given this game a negative review after only playing for a few hours just because they can't beat the AI on the lowest setting. It took me at least 15 hours of practice before I was even able to beat the AI on normal mode. As for all those who have experienced so many gameplay issues I'm not sure what to say as I have so few on such an old machine. My only recommendation is to make sure your drivers are up to date and that you have at least 6GB of RAM. If you are looking for a simple RTS that is easy to pick up and learn with a fun singleplayer experience, and are not feeling up to a frusturating learning curve then this game isn't for you. But if you do want a very complex, fast paced, and balanced game with top notch meta look no further. This game is very strategy oriented and though shares some elements of gameplay with games like Supreme Commander the game overall is completely unique and a breath of fresh air in the long stale world of RTS games.
As for all the complaints about the Titans expansion being a standalone, I think most people are making a far bigger deal about it than it really is. From a business perspective and as a player I commend Uber for going the route they took. Since this was released I've noticed a huge boom in current players in the community. The PA subreddit is far more active and wait times between online matches has been almost non existent waiting at most a minute where before it was who knows when you would get a match. I think this move  was necessary for the game to continue being worked on. The vanilla game has a very poor steam user rating, which can be crippling to game sales, mainly due to the game falling short of promises made during the games early acess phase. Though Uber did finish the game late and still in patchy condition I do defend them on the grounds that over the last year they have been very consistent with updating, improving, and refining the game with regular updates. My only quarrel is making those who purchased the vanilla version on Steam early access... Continued in comments.

reviewText:
I'm torn.

As a standalone title, Planetary Annihilation: TITANS is an amazing RTS, that even includes workshop support to add more content to an already full featured game.

BUT, for those of you who already own Planetary Annihilation, TITANS is a complete rip off, and to be honest is insulting to the people who already own the original game and/or contributed to its kickstarter.

BUT, TITANS is offered at a discount to those who own the original game which brings it down to the price of a typical game expansion...... but only until November.

So taking the game as it is I highly recommend that you play it, because Planetary Annihilation: TITANS as it is, is an amazing game.

But if you consider all that is involved and the stunt that the developers pulled. I cannot recommend it. So make of it as you wish.

Also, I played this on Linux and did not experience the same stability issues that Windows users have experienced. The game seemed very stable.

reviewText:
I am one of the original PA backers. I understand what Uber did with this release considering user reviews, but to be honest I personally don't care. For me, yea, the original PA had it's share of problems like CTD when you destroyed some planet if you did not have the latest graphics drivers (derp on my side), lags in very large battles, etc. I still remember early builds of PA when your land units sometimes became orbital units or fell to the middle of the planet.

The point is, these problems are gone, they have been fixed. What I mean, Uber is still working on the game - every now and then I see PA getting updated with new patch. I am an older gamer and I have seen many games come and go, some good, some bad or unfinished... I am not saying that this game is perfect, but at least for me personally it is enjoyable enough. There is no other game where I can destroy enemy by destroying the very planet he is standing on. When I replay the original Kickstarter video for PA, I now have what I have backed.

I have noticed some reviews where guys were complaining that they cant defeat AI, that it is too hard, etc. I regularly smash AI on normal difficulty, if they really do lose, then they are doing something wrong. Yes it is aggresive, but afaik, it does not cheat and it is beatable.

On the matter of bad reviews. I personally don't care what Uber did or did not as long as they deliver in the end. One of the reasons I am writing this is that I think that much of the backslash this game has gained is now obsolete and I think that game reviews should focus on the quality of the game itself, not the company that makes it as long as the game is not abandoned project. Every reasonable gamer hates Electronic Ars for example, but they sometimes make a good game too ;-)

Lastly, I can't comment on matter of balance, since I don't play multiplayer matches too much. Check other reviews if you are into that kind of thing. If you want to try to crash some planets together or blow them up, this is a game for you. If you are unsure whether or not to buy it, wait for some discount and grab it later - it is not a bad game, it just has some rough edges.

reviewText:
Well, I'm a big fan of this game, so i'll try and keep this review as unbiased as possible.
Pretty much all of the negative reviews are saying is that Uber is satan, the game keeps crashing and that it's not worth the money.
I run this game on a macbook pro that doesn't even meet the minimum system requirements (in terms of processor power) yet it runs fine and only crashes if I do really big games that drag out for too long.
I'm not gonna say what uber did was completely reasonable. I can completely understand why a lot of people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at uber. If you bought the game in early access for $90 and then found that in order to get all of the game's content you'd have to spend another $14 you would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ right?
Only except TITANS was never promised, all of the content in this stand-alone expansion" were never promised anywhere

reviewText:
Yes, there's a little bit of shadyness with asking people to pay for PA again. Especially considering that what they've delivered with TITANS is what they had intended for PA. A last minute PR move to drop the price to $11 (temporarily) for Steam owners of PA, was a move in the right direction.

Unfortunately, TITANS has many of the same tita... very big problems PA had at launch, complete with graphics bugs and crashing everywhere. They're working on it, for sure, but it is still in a state where you will be very lucky if you can ever complete the as yet still feeling empty galactic campagin. I'm sure they'll realease another $50 game in a year that flushes out that portion.

All that negative said, it is still a very playable and fun game... if they can tackle the crashing.

reviewText:
I purchased the original game whilst it was in early access and as a fan of strategy games, i thought it was decent then.  When it was released, i thought that it wasn't quite ready to be released because it was still somewhat buggy and i believe it had left out what some people had thought they were promised.  Uber then proceeded to release updates that made it marginally less buggy.  I personally didn't play it much even after the updates between school and having a computer that ran the game at about 15 frames per second.

Then this came out.

This is what the game should have been at Release.  It's so much more fun and hectic with the titans (especially the ragnarok).  It's also not nearly as buggy as it was when i stopped playing (although i do have a better computer now also).

Now i get the complaints about the whole having to repurchase it thing.  Totally get it.  This definitely should have been a normal, free update for the base game instead of a fully different game.  it is nice that they gave us a discount, but i think it should have been free, especially for the early access purchasers (yes i know it was free for the Kickstarter backers).

Given that, it is a very good game now and i definitely reccomend it.

reviewText:
First off, bare in mind this that recommendation comes IN SPITE of Uber Entertainment's terrible marketing policies (and I'm not just talking about their initial £70 launch on early access!).
This should be a £10 expansion, not a £30 stand alone game.  And really, most of what they added here should have been a free update as PA:Titans is basically what most of us were promised, and expected with PA came out of KS and EA.  The only reason I bought PA:Titans is because they gave owners of PA the 66% discount bringing it in line with what I would expect to pay for a moderate expansion.

All that said, this is a good game.  If you like grand stratagy and the joy of big armies and huge explosions, then this is a worthwhile investment and you can happily sink many hours into the game.
If you already own and enjoyed PA, then get Titans while it's discounted for you.
If you were on the fence with PA, then Titans will not change your mind.
If you don't own PA, then watch video reviews carefully before buying to ensure it's what you want, then get this version and not the original release.

Titans is an all round improvement on the original PA.  Uber have listened to some of the community feedback and suggestions, while remaining totally deaf to others.
The planets are a bit better designed, and the multi-level battlefields make it easier and more fun to build defenciable positions.  There are now more ways to move aroudn the system, the orbital units now feel like a full class rather than a tack-on, and the new units add a pleasent bit of veriety.
Cons-wise, the standard AI still isn't as challanging as I'd like until you're facing more than one, and unit pathfinding can still sometimes go nuts unless you use shift-move to set waypoints.

So, overall a recommend for existing PA fans, and a recommend for non-PA fans who are willing to do their research first (even then it may be better to wait for a sale)

reviewText:
For all the negativity I see from everyone else, I have had 0 issues with this iteration of PA.

This is the full game with an expansion.

People claim the game breaks promises, but there is nothing that was promised this has not met. This is not a Total Annihilation sequel, nor a Supreme Commander Sequel, it is it's own title and it does what it does amazingly.

It has been far more optimised and works brilliantly, and looks beautiful.

Balance has been improved, almost all problems I had with the original game have been fixed.

For the people who say it is a rip-off, they are getting these extras that Uberentertainment did not need to even make for 66% off if they owned the last one.

If you do not even own PA, this is worth the money, buy this, not the previous title.

reviewText:
It’s been said that the RTS genre is dying.

After a Sunday playing this game with friends, I beg to differ.

Planetary Annihilation: Titans is a massive, brilliant game. The game comfortably supports massive armies, battling across a half-dozen worlds, all in a single session.

Multiplayer games are hosted on dedicated servers, which was a great choice. In our games, there were something like ten thousand units between each of our armies plus our AI opponents, all supported with a minimum of latency. The only lag you’ll likely experience is graphical. One of my friends had issues with framerate, but turning down the settings seemed to solve the problem.

You can read other reviews for a list of features. My personal favorites, however are:

+ Multi-planet combat. I enjoyed figuring out ways to transport my army/navy from one planet to another.
+ Balance between orbital, air, and ground/naval combat. Make sure you have an army that can deal with each of them.
+ Lots of fun ways to deal with an entrenched opponent: Nuclear interplanetary missiles, crashing an asteroid into them, activating a freaking DEATH STAR
+ Titan units: In a game that for the most part emphasizes macro, Titans are super fun to micro. The army-teleporting Helios is my personal favorite

Not everything is rosy. We did have a few problems:

- The multiplayer game arrangement interface isn’t great. We sometimes had problems all connecting to the game, and experienced strange, cryptic error messages. Once we were actually IN the game, we had no problems however.
- There’s no automated matchmaking for anything other than 1v1s. I’d love to see a team game and/or FFA matchmaking.

All in all, though, this is a fantastic game. If you’re at all a fan of strategy, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
This is an updated review as I now have the game working and my old review isn’t really relevant anymore.  Originally thumbs downed.  After troubleshooting, I found the issue with running PA:Titans on Windows 10 was caused by Crossfire.  You can find the details of this issue on Ubers forums:

https://forums.uberent.com/threads/bug-report-constant-crashing-cause-found-workaround-found-up-to-uber-coherent-amd-to-fix.70307/#post-1110105

And now for the review (completely subjective and separate from any opinions I have of Uber as a developer):

Now that I have actually played Titans, I can finally talk about the game itself.  I have to say, I am thoroughly enjoying this game.  The gameplay is better.  The UI is better.  The new units are good and create a lot of new tactical possibilities that simply don’t exist in vanilla PA.  A couple units are pretty much throwaways, but others you will find to be integral and regular fielders.  Such as the Tesla bot.  As a tier one bot unit, it's cheap, has high health, great damage and is relatively fast.  Making it an excellent early game spam rush unit.  The new naval units drastically improve naval combat.  The new orbital units are a very welcome inclusion. The new titans themselves, are well implemented.  They’re powerful, but not overpowered.  They’re both game changers and not game changers.  They can sometimes seem like they are a little too easy to build too early.  But they can be countered.  However, as much as I’ve grown to love it, the Ragnarok Doomsday Titan is a little too easy to build.

Seriously, this is probably the most devastating unit in the game.  But has created one of the funniest scenarios I’ve ever experienced in a game.  I was playing AI Skirmish against 3 AI’s in a huge solar system.  Two of the AI’s were on the planet with me pounding me from both sides.  I’m losing the battle on the starting planet.  I’m cutting my losses and going to bail out.  But by this point, they’ve taken orbital superiority of the planet and I’m not getting off the planet by launching into orbit.  Thankfully, early on in the match I had sent a couple orbital fabricators to the metal planet to build a stargate on it.  So I have a couple fabricators building a stargate on the starting planet and any others I can spare building a Ragnarok Titan.  The stargate on the metal planet finally finishes.  I activate the link and send my commander through with a few units and fabricators for defense while I rebuild.  Just as this is happening the Ragnarok finally finishes.  My going away present for the 2 victors is about to be unwrapped.  At this point I realize that I’m now wearing rather sadistic grin on my face.  I close the gate behind me and 60 seconds later, the planet pops.  Eliminating both of the AI commanders that were kicking the crap out of me in one shot.  Needless to say I was lmao for a few minutes.  Then focused on fighting the last AI.

I had repeated games where I was finding that I would win, but I would often win by a different method each time.  Sometimes, by covertly building a stargate in an unoccupied spot on a planet, bring in fabricators, build a Ragnarok and leave before they ever knew I was even there.  Some times by smashing moons or asteroids into planets.  Sometimes with the annihilaser on the metal planet.  Sometimes with traditional warfare.  I never felt forced down any one path.  And it was devilishly fun every time.

Simply put, this game is outstanding. This is the definitive version of Planetary Annihilation. Do I recommend this game.  Absolutely!

-------

Here are some notes and context on the current situation between Uber and its community and how the situation is affecting Titans:

This so called expansion is damn expensive considering what it offers. It should've been marketed as DLC and not a full standalone game/expansion.  Although I can understand why they did it.  The original PA caught a lot of flak and it showed in the reviews.  But it caught that flak, not due to the quality of the game (which admittedly still needed a lot of work), but because of the way Uber treated its community.  Such as Uber attempting to start up another kickstarter without actually finishing PA.  And then in an attempt to call a technical, they claimed PA as fully launched, but released it without key promised features, such as offline mode, requiring an always online connection in order to play the game.  If that wasn’t bad enough, they would flat out refuse to answer the community when they were questioned about these issues.  And on top of that, the people who were talking to the community were often aggressive, offensive and overtly rude.  As a result, a lot of the original PA store page reviews showed the bad blood between the community and Uber and reflected how the community felt about this treatment by Uber.  The thing is, Uber did eventually come around.  They finally released offline mode for PA, replaced the people responsible for interacting with and working with the community (and for the better might I say.  A huge improvement) and continued adding and updating content to PA.  Uber has for quite a while now been mending fences and turning their act around.  The problem, is that the reviews on the PA store page were never updated by the original writers to reflect this and painted a picture of the game that was no longer representative of the games current state.  So, as I said, while I don’t agree with the way they’ve marketed this standalone expansion, I do understand why they took the approach they did.

Fast forward to today and Uber again have put themselves at odds with the community.  Look, I understand that they as a developer need to make money.  We get that.  Everyone gets that.  But Uber need to understand that they are where they are because of the community.  Because when they asked for help, the community rose up and backed them.  Then during early access (EA), new members kept them going by buying the game in EA.  But they didn’t simply support the game for the cost of a game for released retail prices.  They paid well over the value of the game to get EA with Uber charging more during EA than any other developer I’ve ever seen.  There’s no bones about it.  The prices Uber was charging were downright extortionate.  So you can imagine how people would feel when Titans is released, Kickstarter backers get it free, but EA backers are charged for it.  They should’ve given it for free to their Alpha and Beta EA buyers as well.  Their Alpha EA buyers at the very least.  Given what Alpha purchasers paid during EA, it’s insulting for them to be told that they need to pay for the Titans upgrade.  It’s wrong and this is not how you should treat your community.  The alpha buyers gave you a lot and they kept you going through EA.  They deserve to be treated a hell of a lot better than that.  They need to be treated with the respect they deserve.  It’s as simple as that.

To put it quite blunt, you’re shooting yourself in the foot Uber.  It’s a contradiction to release Titans as a standalone expansion in order for it to get up-to-date reviews that are representative of the games current state and then pull what is quite frankly, a d**k move.  You wanted a clean slate and then immediately pulled the same kind of stunt and recreated the exact same scenario that resulted in the state of the reviews on the original PA store page.  The very thing you are trying to distance yourselves from now.  The reviews on the store page are not made by professional reviewers who are required to stay on point and maintain a professional level of objectivity.  They are made by the community and the community is an emotional beast.  Treat them right, and your store page will glow from the love.  Treat them poorly and your store page will show the communities wrath.  You shot yourselves in the foot.  But you still have time to mend the situation.

reviewText:
Pros (+) & Cons (-) in short:

- difficult to understand
+ incredibly big variety in build startegies (Unit types, units, defense, experimental buildings)
- no fractions
+ good balancing (no fractions)
- no skilltrees
+ good balancing (no skilltrees)
- still some (minor) ai bugs
+ Titans (Prototypes)
- no story mode
+ challenging singleplayer mode (skirmish like, but with changed settings like with skill trees)
+ System (Map) designer
+ more content than comparable (all?) RTS games
- long term game (you need to play it a lot)
+ long term game (you are able to play it a lot!)
- game is almost dead


Conclusion: Well made game that is still fun to play, has much content, uncountless strategies and deserves more attention, sadly many people are still mad for reasons that don't change the actual game.






People expect too much, and are easily offended by various strategies of companies. It is a bad thing, that the game has to be bought twice, but it had the price of a dlc for owners of the original game (13$ something).
Also the game is balanced, there are too many reviews about the balance of the game, while the player played only a few hours.The game is big. Incredibly big!
Unlike other RTS Games like Starcraft you won't find the perfect build orders. The game offers you way too many possibilities to play, to find a perfect strategy. And this is one of the reasons why this game is so good, and i recommend it. The game offers much more content than any total annihilation or supreme commander did, with a few exceptions: the skilltree and the fractions.
I liked the skills in SC2 but that they are missing is not too bad, as you can build improved factories, that more or less replace the skilltree.
Then there are no fractions. And even the different commanders are only different in thier look and behave all the same. This also sounds bad, but on the other hand you have now all buildings and units available at once. You don't need to fear that your opponent has walking ships and you mostly low-range units. Well actually this sounds pretty balanced to me, as you can adjust your strategy while playing. In SC2 you were quite f*cked when you realized mid-game that you would have needed another skilltree and mid-game turns end-game suddenly.
The more possibilities in building, adjustment, units, defense system, orbital units, planets & asteroids etc. make it quite difficult to play und understand the game as a beginner. And also, the tutorial sucks. You need to take the time to discover the game by yourself.
That's a reason why many people dislike the game and give bad reviews. Their complaints are mostly about buying the game twice"

reviewText:
Owners of the original Planetary Annihilation are likely to be stubborn in purchasing this new expansion and I can understand why however at 66% off it is a great deal considering you get:

Many new units filling the gaps left by original unit cast.
Titans allowing interesting mid-late game fights and overcoming major stalemates over planet camping.
The ability to have chokepoints in maps (I feel as if this should be put into the base game however).
Most of all actual space battles due to battlecruisers and new orbital units.

Like with the original however if you pc doesn't have a fast quad core (3GHz or higher) and 8+ GB of RAM preferrably 12GB for large maps do not purchase. If you do however it is one of the most complex and rewarding RTS games available.

Edit: If you feel you should be entitled to the expansion without buying it since you owned the original please vote with your wallet by not buying the game. I just wanted to buy it to let people know if it is worth buying if you really like the game and wanted more out of it.

reviewText:
Love it or Hate it Review Simulator 2015

I hadn't played much of PA since early after release, and while I had fun with a few friends for a while, the glitches and lack of polish at the time really put a dampner on it that I felt it was quite a dissapointment, and the fun kinda fizzled out.

Roll on to the Titans release (and a 1gb patch to the original game to go with it), and everything seems much more like I was hoping it would have been previously.  The game feels better optimised, the UI has had large improvements and it just feels like a much more fun game to play.

A word of caution though, and hence the title at the top.  If you are reading through these reviews, take some of them with a pinch of salt (Maybe buckets of Salt in some cases :p), there are a number of people unhappy with the way that some owners of PA got copies of Titans for free, and just going through and downvoting any positive review and upvoting any negative review, regardless of the review's content.

If you are interested in this game and want to know whether to buy it, bear that in mind when reading the reviews, or go take a look on twitch at people streaming it to get a better sense of how it plays.

reviewText: I'm going to review this as someone who wasn't a kickstarter backer, but someone who throughouly enjoyed the original Planetary Annhilation, thus I paid 13 dollars for this DLC. This is also going to be short and to the point.\n\nThe original PA had its problems. It had performaces issues, a lack of variety, and not enough content to engage for that long. It was engaging though, and for the time it held my attention, I enjoyed it a lot. Titans, as DLC, adds a lot of things that I wanted into the game. New terrains features make the planets feel more alive, rather than just flat circles with the occasional ocean. There can be ridges and mountains now, which adds a new layer to base building, Before, you could practically anywhere, but now you have to think where you are going to place yourself based on terrain features. This was a small addition, but the biggest thing was the new units. All of the units have their place, and I have found myself using some of the new units very frequently. All methods of combat have been improved, but what has been improved the most is Orbital combat. There are plenty of new Oribital units that make space battles a lot more interesting than before (as there was just one real attacking unit that could be in Orbit, which were those little fighters). Now you can have much larger battle cruisers that can also shoot beams down to the planet below. The new units have added a lot to the game. Sadly, I have not had a chance to try out using a Titan" (I have been playing Galactic Conquest and have not unlocked the technology) but I have had them used against me. They certainly do live up to their namesake. They are collasal

reviewText:
I kickstarted this game at a high level, and followed its progress the whole way through.

People are upset that the people that were there from the beginning are being rewarded for funding a game /that would never of been created/ if it were not for the kickstarter backers that were there from the start.

People are upset claiming that these features were promised for the original version, when in fact they were not. Being a part of the kickstarter, I can tell you that every major feature made it into the game. The fact that a kickstarted project that only had a pre rendered video to start off with turned out to be this close to the vision is an absolutely incredible feat.

Uber really put their heart into this, and they really did a great job creating an RTS unlike anything anyone has ever seen. Its an absolute SHAME that people are out there, creating their own expectations, and blaming the company when their own expectations are not met.

Guess what, the game was not for you then. Don't go blaming Uber for that. They made an incredible, diverse, and compelling title. These reviews floating to the top of the steam page are literally the worst trolls that you see in the gaming community, and I'm sick of seeing them.

Please check out this game. It is currently on sale for about 14 bucks, and is worth well more than that if you really dig RTS games.

reviewText:
Fun little gamebut not very challenging if you are playing versus AI. Not even on harder settings. Playing against Normal AI is pointless, and also against Hard AI. it takes like 4 minutes to deal with Hard AI by just building an advanced factory and make a queue of some bots or tanks that walk into the enemy base. No resistance whatsoever.

Nice and simple graphics, and you just can't wait for that beautiful mushroom cloud to appear over your enemy commander.  Some of the bots make some very cute sounds, and it hurts a little when you send them to their death :(

I would love to see more variations of units, instead of all commanders having the same loadout, perhaps.

CONS: Unfortunately the game is extremely buggy at this point, with lots of graphical problems. I have to restart the game at least every 45 minutes or so. Either graphics bug out, or I end up with no bots visible at all. I have a multi monitor setup, and it keeps forcing new windows to open up BEHIND all other previously opened program windows. I guess this is how lazy code monkeys solve the always-on-top feature of their game.

The planets are too small in Galaxy War, and there are too few of them and not with enough variations.  You literally end up spawning next to your enemy, and you can just walk over and kill the enemy with your own commander as soon as you get any kind of health or weapons boost. It's pretty stupid to be honest. The planets always have the same spawn points, so you quickly learn where the enemy has spawned too. And for some weird reason, the AI will ALWAYS spawn on your own planet - even in multi-planet systems. Stupid.

I'm not sure why they added the Titans to be honest. At least when playing Galaxy War, you don't even have to bother with the Titan technology unlock. You never need it. It simply takes too long time to build the Titans, and the game is over long before you even would consider building it.

reviewText:
Amazing Planetary Annihilation 'sequel'. Don't get fooled by the reviews about how weird marketing model Uber is using, PA kickstarter bakers get the game for free, PA owners get it cheap (15$, DLC-like), and new players get it at PA price (39$ i believe).

The game overall is way better and fun than the original PA, the new multilevel terrain is amazing, terrain is not anymore the place your units stand on, it's the place your strategy releases on. You will have trouble attacking a well built base, even if you have unit superiority.

The offensive TITANs are amazing, they can change the match, but don't think of them as 'instant game winner', they will get easily killed if you don't have a good army behind them.

There are also strategic TITANs, for example the 'Elios', which can link to a teleporter, and drop a devastating attack to any place in any planet.

There are also some new units. They are awesome, ranging from amphibious vehicles, to a swarm of nanobots that destroys anything it touches!

Some new buildings are avaible too, for example, a 'dox' (light attack bot) launcher, the 'lob', to quickly surprise the enemy.

I completely recommend the game to any previous PA user, and to any user interested in RTS games.

reviewText: A little while ago I got Planetary Annihilation from a humble bundle. I bought the bundle to try out Xenonauts, but was pleasantly surprised at Planetary Annihilation. Then I noticed that my version wasn't on the steam store, only the newer Titans standalone was there. I was very hesitant because all of the top reviews were mostly negative and many people in the discussions seemed very hostile, though I understand their anger they backed a game an now they have to pay extra for the newer version. Despite this I bought this game and I am glad I did. There are many issues with the game, like long loading times, the game seems to hang when loading menus, sometimes the game doesn't save, and there is the occasional crash. However, I love this game overall, please note that I only play with bots I don't know how performance is online. I love the units added in this expansion the Omega orbital unit being my favorite, an it is satisfying to shell an enemy base with artillery fire from the Holkins artillery defense. No other game that I can recall lets me destroy other planets to rid of annoying enemy. The only thing that I really hope for is some sort of auto save, because as with most games I tend to lose track of time and if the game does crash I often lose all or most of my progress in the battle.

reviewText:
If you haven't picked up Planetary Annhilation yet, then this is a great time to do so. TITANS adds so many new ways to bring about chaotic destruction on your enemies; combined with the newer features such as asteroids, game saving, resume from replay, its far ahead in features of the admittably poorly timed release of Planetary Annihilation (sans TITANS). While there may be some optimization gains yet to be had, the game plays reliably enough to be fun much more than it is frustrating. Lobbying is no longer a waiting game, and for those who prefer to go it alone, the AI gets more devilish with each passing month, and the  dedicated single player mode has received some much needed revamps. I personally am a huge fan of the map editor - this tool alone gives Planetary Annihilation, and TITANS by extension, so much variation and replayability to be worth the asking price alone. The map editor is quite powerful and can create some truly striking maps. The fact that the engine plays along with your monstrous creations without a fuss really shows just what a great job Uber Entertainment has done. Not to mention that mods are all but officially supported, and you have hundreds of hours of entertainment for even tentative RTS fans. The developers are fairly involved; not only can you often post on the forums and get a reply, but they also hang around in the in-game (modded-in) chat (look for PA Stats) and answer questions. As someone who played a lot of Command and Conquer, especially Red Alert, back in my day, I have to say that I really enjoy this take on the RTS genre; and as someone who rarely played online in my Command and Conquer days, I have to say that online mode is a lot more accessible for newbies and hardcore players alike.

TL;DR: Buy this game, it is absolutely better than before. Definitely worth it if you don't own the original Planetary Annihilation, and I personally still think worth it even if you own PA. If you're feeling cheap... well there will probably be sales, given how often the first iteration of PA went on sale.

FYI, I have over 400 hours with the first Planetary Annhilation, in case you are scared off by the much smaller TITANS game time.

reviewText:
I recommend this game because it is a fresh new concept. Pretty cool and fun. However, I share the disapointments among the community.

The company itself is pretty shady. They released this game in a manner considered unfinished by the majority of the backers and supporters. Also no one likes to compare but the fact of the matter is that this game will always be compared to similar games like Supreme Commander Forged Alliance and although a new and cool idea, fails to bring the scale and depth of what Supreme Commander Forged Alliance has to offer.

The problem is that you can clearly see where the devs cut corners and took shortcuts to rush this out instead of giving you something better. A very simple and clear example is the fact that there is only one faction while its predecessors have 4 factions. Major short-cut number 1 if you ask me. No bubble shields... No experimentals until now in Titans... You would think that with there being only one faction that there would be a lot of unique units within this faction but no... They skimped on that as well. Everywhere you look, they cut corners to rush this out. They gave less than the minimum expected to the supporters of this game.

This stand alone expansion Titans" is really closer to what the game everyone expected to be released... But instead they sold these adittional units
recommended: sounds etc..as an expansion which in my opinion was wrong.\n\nAll in all I still recommend the game because it is fun to play skirmish in coop against the ai. It does deliver a unique experience. But really these developers were really shady holy crap."

reviewText:
I'm an avid RTS player and Planetary Annihilation, while it's hard to call it the best (not that it isn't, just too many classics like C&C and Company of Heroes series in the genre) I've played, it's easily one of the best and more importantly, the most unique one.

The multi-planet combat was the main selling aspect of Planetary Annihilation to me, and the charming art style on top of the extremely flexible and accessible System Editor are the defining features of Planetary Annihilation to me.

There were a few hickups in gameplay, mostly in that lockdown scenarios were a bit too easy to pull off on smaller planets, locking the game down, but the developers have elegantly solved these issues by adding and tweaking many features to keep you on your toes all the time before nailing the problem completely with Titans. It is truly a fast paced game that can slow down just enough for you to realize that your planet's moon refuses to be a slave anymore, and I'm confident in the expansion's ability to further cement that description.

The Helios titan gets a special shout-out for completely changing the way you invade a planet, and the game is better for it.

The new units like the hover tank, the hover ship, the solar drone and the heavy bomber fill niches I didn't realize existed, and they manage to set themselves distinct in use from anything in the vanilla PA roster while blending in perfectly. There's no art style disparity to speak of, and even the Titans look very true to the game.

Stalemates can still happen but there are even more ways to break them. Establishing a foothold and then destroying the target planet is now directly possible via the Ragnarok titan, adding another method of destroying an enemy base.

I fully encourage any RTS player to purchase this game, and especially those who may have had similar thoughts regarding the original as I did, as the improvement will be noticable for the latter right away. The new players will find this game to be refreshing if they are already accustomed to the RTS genre, but they should be aware that feeling overwhelmed, especially at the later stages of the game is very normal for the average player and it will never go away. The game is macromanagement oriented, and I believe wraps up what you're signing up for.

Go for it!

reviewText:
To all those reviews saying how they didn't include everything promised, THEY INCLUDED EVERY FEATURE PROMISED IN THE KICKSTARTER. This is a standalone expansion, likely to get away from the reviews that were made years ago in early access that haven't been updated.

The game has come along way, and is a good RTS in it's own right. The Titans expansion (Which is only 13 dollars for people who already own the game, cheaper than most expansions are these days) does add quite a bit, as well as optimization and bug fixes for the game. I've found no bugs in the game, despite some reviews calling the game a buggy mess" only after having a half hour in the game.

The game is fun
date: and I've found little to no bugs. There's quite a number of units to build
recommended: and I'm not sure of another game that allows you to kill the enemy by throwing their planet into the sun."

reviewText:
I love this game. They've polished it up a lot since the original PA release. Galactic War is now fairly entertaining and playable. The UI enhancements are many and appreciated. The TITANS are pretty hilarious, like the rest of the game-ending super weapons (death star-like planet destroying laser, crashing planets into other planets, nuke spam).

I like this a lot better than SC II and similar games for a couple reasons. I like the 'flow-based' economy more than the harvesting economy present in the majority of RTS these days. I also like the focus on large scale in terms of unit and structure count. Build queues can be set absurdly deep, or you can just set a mix and put unit-producing factories on endless repeat.

The result is really huge engagements and lots of flexibility.

There is a great co-op mode (this was present in the original PA), where you share resources and units against the opposing team. It helps if you have unequal skill levels--you can have the less skilled players micromanage battles or invasions or economic expansion and they'll still have fun.

I consider this an improvement over PA. I believe there is a discount available if you own the original PA. If you are a Kickstarter backer I believe you get it for free!

reviewText: Planetary Annihilation just took a titanic step forward. I'm glad that Uber finally took the time to do all this extra work that they had never promised anyone they would do. The community has been talking about things like this for a looong time, and Uber has gone pretty above and beyond in listening. The only area I think needs more love at the moment is orbital, though it has definetly improved. I'm glad they took a hint from the popularity of my Orbital Warfare Overhaul mod (shameless plug). I'm massively enjoying the new units, balance and gamplay this expansion provides. I will update this review once I get more time to play around with all the new toys!

reviewText: For all the bad reviews. Notice that guys that give the bad reviews only play the game for less then an hour. Yes the game has had some issues. But name a game that has not had issues ever with launch including alot of big titles had some issues. If you love basebuilding and resource gathering this is the game for you. At first when I played I felt overwhelmed but there are alot of hotkeys and with experience the game is very easy. I mean its an RTS where I can actually eat and play. Its not like starcraft 2 fast paced but not slow like civ 5. I give this game 4 out of 5 stars. I would give it 5 out of 5 once they hammer out the minor server problems. I play this game on a duo core E8400 with a nvidia gtx 750. Not the best specs but definitely can play on medium settings with good fps. For all the haters of this game. Play the game for at least 20 hours before you give a bad review. Everybody has the same units so it is balanced. And let me tell you there are tons of ways to annihilate your enemy. If you love RTS you will love this game.

reviewText:
I like it, adds some mid/late game complexity with the Titan units.

Whatever problems this game had during early access and launch are now resolved.

It's a solid expansion at a decent DLC price for those that have the game, and it's a fully functional start point for those who don't have it.

Performance still could use optimization, so don't play the big matches with many planets unless you've got a beefy rig.
